So sorry to hear this. "Tharki", a common hindi team to describe, h*rny, desperate, is what most men are. They feel a sense of entitlement to do anything, especially when they get some alcohol in their system. Unfortunately, you see this a lot from the less literate people who haven't been exposed to the world (not like there aren't educated predators). It's more the fascination of seeing a white person in the flesh that they've been seeing online. It's like giving a baby a new toy, so they want to explore it. I do not suggest any person travelling alone, unless you are a seasoned one and have the grit to handle the sh*t that comes your way. I'm Indian and my white wife (then girlfriend) backpacked North-South India in 2016 for over 3 months and trust me it wasn't easy navigating it, but we had the best time ever exploring this beautiful country and diverse culture. In my experience, the people in the South are more receptive and civilized than North India - just because they've had more exposure. I would strongly recommend visiting India but do take necessary precautions, good planning and would only recommend a group tour through a reputed organization, one that has a good social media following with proof and reviews. Cheers!

Mujhe Dubai me ek incident yaad hai. Humare family ke just peeche aur ek Indian group tha. Normal line tha, Burj ke lift se neeche utarne ke liye. Boht dur tak line tha, kafi obvious tha ki log ek ke bad ek samne jayenge. Humlog thori der dhyan nhi de rhe the achanak uncle mujhe cross karke samne jaane wale the with his group. Mai boli ap kaha ja rhe hai humlog hai. Matlab line ka kuch lihaaz nhi hai kichu nhi hai. Unko lagta hai samne jane me thora gap kya hua to wo samne aise hi line cut kar sakte hai. To wo piche ja hi rhe the to unko samne se koi bulaya ye bolke ki humare sathe hai. Wo wahi excuse ab mujhe deke samne chale gaye.

Line zigzag shape me ja rha tha. To isliye do line the Jo lift ke pas the- ek tha ek corner jaha U turn murke phir u turn leke last lift pe charne wala line aa rha tha. (Samajhna thora muskil hai, picture nhi ha) To wo uncle and unke helper wale ka jo bara group tha wo log soche ki wo u turn line hi last line hai, next unhi logo ko waha se charne denge. Airport check in jaisa line ka concept kaise samajh nhi aya idk, lekin wo log wahi khare rehe. Notice hi nhi kiye ki age jana hai. Normally waise situation me we tell people ki age chaliye. I said nothing, bas aise hi cross karke line me age nikal gye. Phir unlog ko samajh aya ki line dusre jaga se khulta ha . Piche se clearly sunai par rha tha bol rhe hai koi baat nhi etc etc. Humlog jab lift me charhe uske bhi 1 ya times bad charhe honge wo group ke log.

Basic decency Boht kam hai yaha ke logo me. I was very sad ki aise behaviour se humlog ko represent kar rhe hai foreign jagah me. Kitne sare desh ke log the, sab ka normal civics sense wala behaviour tha. And humare desh ke logo ko waha bhi line katna, grouping karna normal laga. Agar wo request karte, if I'm not in a hurry, mai aise hi allow kar deti hu logo ko. Mujhe bura laga tha ki aise behaviour se mai associated hu, in whatever way  Anyways, humlog sirf khud ko hi represent kar sakte hai. Baki log kya kare hum par nhi hai. Bas accha encourage hi kar sakte hai. Desh ko zaleel jo hona tha aise hi ho rhe hai

If you look india from my perspective it is one of the oldest civilizations in the world, India is a mosaic of multicultural experiences. With a rich heritage and myriad attractions, the country is among the most popular tourist destinations in the world. It covers an area of 32, 87,263 sq. km, extending from the snow-covered Himalayan heights to the tropical rain forests of the south, which give the country a distinct geographical entity.
Fringed by the Great Himalayas in the north, it stretches southwards and at the Tropic of Cancer, tapers off into the Indian Ocean between the Bay of Bengal on the east and the Arabian Sea on the west. 
India has 2400 KMs of himalayan mountain ranges, 7500 KM of coastline with some average , but some beautiful and stunning beaches , india has around 13000 islands , it has a Desert(Thar) and the  place with most rainfall in the world is also in india(Assam), it has a number of huge national park and wild life sanctuaries with rare animals and species which includes the majestic Royal Bengal Tiger, Asiatic lions , Rhino's, elephants , bears etc. Different types of flora and fauna , it has gift of spectacular ancient architecture with thousand of years old temples and cities , also upcoming  modern architecture, India's infrastructure is growing at a scale which is highest in the world , 27 cities now have metro trains or work in progress .with the highest GDP growth among major economies, india is transforming rapidly
As you travel the expanse of the country, you are greeted by diverse nuances of cuisines, faiths, arts, crafts, music, nature, lands, tribes, history and adventure sports. India has a mesmeric conflation of the old and the new. As the bustling old bazaars rub shoulders with swanky shopping malls, and majestic monuments accompany luxurious heritage hotels, the quintessential traveller can get the best of both worlds. Head to the mountains, enjoy a beach retreat or cruise through the golden Thar, India has options galore for all.

Thanks for the honest video. On the personal questions issue I should say sometimes even we Indians find some of the queries uncomfortable. But as a rule the standards for a question being personal are somewhat different from the West. India is a family centric society, so asking questions about one's family is deemed quite normal (wanting to see your sister's photo is definitely not). If I bring a friend of mine, Indian or not, the very first questions they are gonna face are like "What's your name?", "What's your father's name?", "What does he do?", " Does your mom work also?", " Who else are there in your family?" and the like. Even, at times people may feel ignored if not asked such questions after being acquainted for the first time. Here 'living with parents' does not have the disapproving stigma attached to it. Rather, it's the opposite, it's what expected of good, grown-up and caring and responsible children.

I live in India. The trash problem is very frustrating. People have(in general) very less awareness of what they are doing. Public cleanliness is not a part of life for many people. It won't be wrong to say that people are lazy in that regard as many people won't bother to go to throw garbage in the bin even if it is 10 steps away. They just throw it right there on the ground and sometimes in water too. At many places,there's no garbage collection system and hence people are forced to do it. So, government needs to work on that. But what I've noticed traveling around India is that there will be places where you'd not see a piece of trash and you'll find parts of the country very filthy. North is more polluted than the South. West isn't really great when it comes to cleanliness. Northeast is better in that regard. The government has been pushing Swachha Bharat (clean India) mission rigorously through awareness, advertising and all. It has yielded good results but there is a very long way to go. 
I feel cleanliness is a habit. If it becomes a habit, it won't go away.
The other cons you mentioned are also largely true. I relate to them as someone who lives here.
I am an Indian and I absolutely agree with all the cons.

I am really sorry for "cons" that you have faced. But I think I should point to few of the things. India is a diverse country in every aspect. 1.3 Billion people. Huge class differences are there in terms of money, education, culture. People that are bothering and cheating you are from the bottom of the list, most of the Indians avoid them too. And yes plan your journey properly, you will get app for home delivery of everything, from communication, food, vegetables, medicine etc. Buy train tickets reserved or unreserved from app. Please do not mind, but I have to say this that if you are not on a very tight budget then please book at least AC second class. If you go below that you will continue to get whatever you are already getting. As you are a foreigner your currency is very strong here, though I don't think you have not done any hard work to make your currency stronger, cheaters will try to get advantage of your strong currency. I always see foreigners are saying "India is So cheap." -- it is not, your currency is strong. One more thing, when people are asking you personal question, they have already started judging you, be aware. I am not saying that these problems are not present, they are there. Agreed. Most of us don't like them too. So we stay and go to places where things are better and easy for us.

Everything you have said is true but I have to mention most of them don't really apply to regular tourists. And for traveling and hotels online booking and payments are much appreciated. Avoid tuk tuk Use Uber and Ola. You need to learn to say no to people who ask for selfies and ask unnecessary questions.

I will try to give my pov on each cons:
Garbage issue: this is going to take a fundamental change in the mentally of the ppl, but I also think authorities haven't done enough to curb this problem, there is no proper waste management system esp in smaller towns and cities, also they need to lay down strict rules and hv heavy fines on culprits, things will change. Same ppl when go to foreign countries follow these rules and don't throw litter outside.
Scams and cons: because of the sheer no. Of ppl here, the no. Of such will always be higher, but I think in % they are low, most of us will always try and help you out.
Stray animals: well this is a cultural thing, can't judge anything keeping Western lenses, like many Indians will find keeping animals in fences and chains is regressive and that they shd be free to roam.
Personal space and selfies: I just don't understand the obsession re selfies with foreigners, nut in general if personal space is your thing then this country is not for you. We are very social ppl and it's very common to ask questions like what does my parents do, what do I do for living, I'm married or not. But asking for a pic of your sister is very very weird, even for us. So stay away from such ppl without worrying whether you looking like rude, if you feel awkward, just ignore, don't pay attention.
SIM cards and train tickets: again the govt and authorities needs to do more for tourism and make these things easy. Though I have watched some vlogs in which ppl hv said it's very easy to get SIM cards at airport and that irctc website accepts international cards, do check vlogs by Ivana Perkovic or Christine Kaaloa.

In general, India is very diverse country, in one city itself you will find many different kind of ppl. For e.g. in Pune where I live, You will find the cleanest of areas where ppl won't bother you with selfies, ppl displaying pda, girls wearing anything they want and then in other areas you will also find the things you mentioned. It's just up to ppl what they are seeking here and truth of this country is a mix of all these things.

Good video bro. Thanks for sharing. But it seems to me that you're wandering in a lot of poor areas and that's what you seem to be describing for most part. Its like going to ghetto or slums in the US and describing the experience :) agree with the bad garbage ethics though

Uttar Pradesh and Bihar are the most underdeveloped, populated, less literate states of India. I have been to at least 15 states in India. In India, Uttar Pradesh ( Agra) and Bihar are the dirtiest states. Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Punjab are lot cleaner. North East India Sikkim, Meghalaya, Arunachal Pradesh etc are cleaner than North India. Overall South Indian states like Goa, Kerala, Tamil Nadu are much cleaner and people are literate.  In major cities like Delhi, New Delhi is clean and green but Old Delhi is dirty and sketchy. In Mumbai, South Mumbai is cleaner but suburbs are not clean. I  think you are generalising and exaggerating things.  You said people throw garbage in the river. Actually it's not a garbage but flowers and Garlands which they throw. Especially in Temple towns like Varanasi. After Prime Minister Modi launched Clean India Mission the Sanitation coverage in India is over 98%. Overall people have been made aware of cleaneliness. People in major cities have started segregating dry and wet waste.  I would say the older generation was illierate and way dirtier. The current generation is more cleaner and literate.  So it will take another twenty years or a generation more for India to be a cleaner country. As India gets Richer, the government will have more money for waste management but it's the mindset of Indians which needs to be changed.   Cheers from Mumbai

You will see India how you want to see it.
Many tourists from G7 countries go along the Golden Triangle because it is replete with monuments, forts, palaces, temples and 17th century bazaars. Many tourists from these countries are hopping from monument to monument with smart English-speaking guides.
Tourists from Russia are only interested in Goa, this is because they look for places with warm climate, warm waters, affordability, easy availability of alcohol and relaxed dress codes. Goa seems to fulfill those categories.
Tourists from Israel, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Malayasia are interested in visiting Shimla, Manali and Dharmasala. Some have even travelled to Gulmarg and Pahalgam. This is because these places have cold weather and are the cheapest places for them to experience snowfall.
Students from Iraq, Iran and African countries visit Pune and Bangalore.
Finally Bangladeshi tourists are only interested in shopping malls of Kolkata and in drinking.

Official Language is not only Hindi, India has 22 official languages including Hindi and English. Hindi is just most spoken language of India.

1) Best transportation to use in India is metro. India has the 8th largest metro system in the world. Currently, metro operates in 15 major cities of India.
2) Except Uber, India also has Ola app for travelling.
3) Indian people don't depend on using cards or atm much as we have unified payment interface (UPI) system which allows us to pay/transfer money directly through the mobile.
4) India is very safe, just avoid going to shady places, cheap hotels and avoid Old Delhi type of places at all cost.
5) India's food is very rich with spices and street foods are made with loads of spices which a foreigner's stomach is not used to. I would suggest to avoid street food as much as possible. Better to go to hotels and restaurants.

Don't you mean the South being vegetarian vs North being non vegetarian?  Udipi style cuisine, in the South, is pure vegetarian...look for a town named Udipi/Udupi.  That's my heritage...what my parents grew up eating...and I like. It's part of me. North is more of Mughlai meat curries. Mumbai is seafood baby...all the way!!!...not to mention Parsi style also....Parsi as in Freddie Mercury (Farokh Bulsara) and Parsi. Goa is very heavily Portuguese influence in food and in religion and architecture. 

Also the trains are what made India.  Maybe it's because my tata (grandfather) was a railway inspector on Western Railways in Mumbai, along with many Uncles working in the railways. 

Additionally, you glanced right over the Deccan and Bangalore, Mysore, Coimbatore, and Ooty. Maybe for me, it's because of family. Bangalore is the third city that makes up the economic "locomotive" of India. Bangalore reminds my of California at the elevation of Denver. While Bangalore is a bit overbuilt, Mysore is beautiful...if you like palaces, yoga retreats, and studying culture and religion. Many beautiful outdoor parks also. 

FYI I happen to like the meter gauge railroad trip from Coimbatore to Ooty... actually have to switch trains in between, to connect to meter gauge train going up the mountain....and you can see them engage the cogwheel going up the grading to the Niligiri tea plantation areas around Ooty. 

BTW, between Delhi and Mumbai, if you have the time, take the Mumbai Rajdhani Express Train instead of the airplane.  It's and experience... particularly in AC first class sleeper car..... nothing like Amtrak. You can also take the Gharib Rath Express Train. 

Also, the Southernmost point of mainland India on Cape Comorin lies a hamlet called Ashramam in Kanyakumari District of Tamil Nadu (Kerala border). That is my father's native place as they call it in India (place where my father's family originates from)... beautiful place where the Indian Ocean, Arabian Sea, and Bay of Bengal meet.

I went to India too! I was born in India but I came to America when I was really young. Anyway I didn't really remember it much, I didn't remember anything actually haha I just know what there is to know about my religion, Hinduism, my parents have taught me all they know but I didn't really get to experience the live culture until this past summer. I went to India after 13 years, and my reactions were exactly the same as yours. I went to north and south India. In the north I stayed mainly in Lucknow and New Delhi, then in south India I went to Chennai. I also went to Lumbini, Nepal, where Buddha was born. I saw the Indian and Nepal border. I visited my extended family after like 13 years. Even though I didn't have memories with them it was very easy to get along and enjoy because blood is just blood, I am also fluent in Hindi so that made everything easier. My first few days sucked but I got used to their lifestyle. I don't look Indian, somehow cuz I'm 100% Indian, but yeah people were ripping me off as well. I was also surprised seeing dogs everywhere, I felt so bad but that's just how it is in India lol there are cute homeless dogs everywhere. You brought back so many amazing memories from my trip to India! I miss it like crazy, I was there for one month and it was the best experience of my life. I learned so much and I traveled, met new people, saw different lifestyles, experienced my culture and religion, it was just an amazing experience and I came to realize multiple things, one being seeing how privileged we really are in America. I also HATED the bathrooms there haha the toilet seat was ALWYAS wet after your shower because there isn't anything that separates the toilet from the shower. No tp didn't take long to get used it, their version is way cleaner lol. The electricity went on and off. Haha anyway street shopping is awesome in India, because everything is so cheap. I hope you don't forget to street shop! Make sure you bargain (I had skilled aunties who I went shopping with and always got amazing deals on clothes and accessories, like I would get amazing stuff which in American dollars would cost maybe $2 lol nice shoes, sandals, heels, stylish clothing (maybe not branded but hey looks nice!) ). India was just an eye opening experience for me.

India is a developed country, and will very soon take over the US as the world number 1 super power. The whole country (cities, towns, villages) are vastly clean, very modern and futuristic, with zero crime rate and absolutely zero pollution. There are no slumps, shit-holes, ghettos or poor uneducated hungry people in any corner of India. Each and every Indian is well educated, dead honest, equally wealthy and prosperous. Its police force holds the reputation of having the highest global standards of integrity, is very clean, corruption-free, humane, competent and professional in their jobs - they don't take bribes or beat ordinary citizens brutally on the streets with batons or long rods like what you usually see in bollywood movies. 5 Reasons Why India Is the Dirtiest and the Most Polluted Country in The World

What is the first thing that comes to your mind when you hear India? Most people will answer cows, toilets, Bollywood, the Taj Mahal, and high rape rates.

All these assessments are not wrong, considering that this country, which is located at the South Asian region has more negative sides than positive sides.

India is known as a backward and outdated country. Its social problems are very complex.

Apart from the issue of rape, most parts of India are slums, which impress people from all over the world, that they are filthy and dirty. This is also proven by surveys from various research institutions which place India at the top of the list of the dirtiest countries with the highest levels of pollutants in the world.

5 reasons India is the most polluted country

1. Poverty

India often boasts about its rapid economic development, but a survey by the Rangarajan Committee shows that more than 38% of the population live below the poverty line in 2023.

With great poverty, most residents live in inappropriate places such as riverbanks, slums.

2. Density

India is one of the most densely populated countries in the world with very limited natural resources compared to its booming population. Its population reaches 1.4 billion.

Poverty and density are the 'right' combination to create a slum and polluted environmental situation. Garbage, human waste, animal waste is strewn everywhere on the streets of India, the large number of vehicles and related things certainly make India look so dirty and filthy.

3. Don't care about the surrounding environment

There is an interesting fact from the primitive lifestyle of Indians. They tend not to care about the surrounding environment.
This is because Indians think that public facilities are the responsibility of other people, especially the government. So even though a lot of rubbish has piled up, even though it disturbs the view and causes an unpleasant smell, it's all left alone. Even though outsiders think this is very sad, Indians, whose mindset is backward and uncivilized, have become accustomed to this situation.

4. Caste Mentality

It is common knowledge that Indian society, which is predominantly Hindu, knows caste in their life. Because of these social norms, people who feel they belong to a higher class tend not to want to do work that is identical to that of people from the strata below them.

5. Government Services

India is a very poor country. This results in minimal government services and attention to environmental issues. Such as widening waterways, emptying trash cans and so on.

I am in India as of this comment on a 7-day trip to Delhi. This is my second time in India and I am hungry for more. My first trip back in 2016 was to Mumbai where I spent most of my time in Powai. I was fascinated by the culture, the sights, the nature, and the contrast between old and new parts of the city as well as its rich, middle class, and slum areas. My best memory from the trip was one hell of a hike in the Sanjay Gandhi National Park, which is a recommendation I cannot make enough if you ever find yourself in Mumbai, especially the view from the top, which is surreal to say the least! I just concluded a full day in Agra yesterday and looked at a few monuments and local artisan workshops which was very rich and which I also recommend to anyone coming to Agra in addition to visiting the Taj Mahal, of course. My discovery of the massive land of India is still in its infancy and I look forward to the next trip! The one thing I still cannot get used to is the aggressive driving, be it here in Gurgaon (where I'm staying), in Agra yesterday, or in Powai a few years back! The excessive use of horns becomes background noise that you get used to and filter out eventually.

I backpacked alone as a female traveler for 2 months in India when I was 22 years old. I visited all the mentioned places plus some. It was by far the hardest country to travel in I‚Äôve ever tried even to this date 13 years later and 70+ countries visited. So many inappropriate comments from men, heckling and I‚Äôve left hotels/hostels sooner rather than planned due to feeling very unsafe from the male staff. However, I also truly had an amazing trip and do not regret going. I travelled aloned, mainly stained in hostels, planned my own trips and transport which means I never had to deal with ‚Äúguides‚Äù or ‚Äúdrivers‚Äù. Just normal tuktuk and taxi drivers, took the train on the third class (packed with locals with rats running around the floor) and felt completely safe. 

I know I was lucky that nothing too bad happened to me. But to be fair, I met mostly normal people on the street which were very kind. Yes, cat-calling, being followed and offered opium straight up on the street is a strange experience. Would I recommend India for anyone? Absolutely not. For an experienced traveller who is willing to take the risk? Yes, for sure, it‚Äôs a stunning country. Would I go back? Nope, too hard and not worth the risk for me any more. I fully recommend going to Nepal, Bhutan or Sri Lanka instead. Felt the most safe in those countries - even more than SE Asian countries.

I am an Indian living in Europe, and I am truly sorry to hear about your experience. I can understand the deep cultural differences at play. I want to help you and others make sense of this issue. One of my Russian friends in Goa manages this by charging 500 rupees per photo and asking people to form a line, with no touching allowed. This strategy can work in some cases. Hey, brown Indian guy right here üëã. I totally see where you‚Äôre coming from and even agree with you a 100%. The problem here is, no matter how hard you try to ‚Äúeducate‚Äù or help people here, it‚Äôs all to no avail. 1. India is REALLY corrupt. Well, I don‚Äôt even need to say much, the whole world knows about this. Even females born in India are reluctant to go anywhere after dark in most places here, let alone tourists. I was in India three times in the late 1970s and experienced it all on a much lower scale, harassment from people trying to sell something or Western women occasionally being harassed while seeking company from other Westerners for protection. At that time there were already reports of Dowry murder cases and women who had acid shed on them. Nevertheless, as a Westerner you were not nearly as harassed as is described in today's reports. People were more curious about young travelers from the West and hospitable. But what was already noticeable back then was the extreme, Victorian-like sexual repression of society. Young men asked for porn magazines. There were early reports of ultrasound scans of pregnant women who did not want female babies. There was also a mixture of inferiority complexes and a lack of distance towards people from the West. I think that the Internet, social media and smartphones have exacerbated the situation for Western travelers in recent decades. A strange mix comes together. On the one hand, pride in India's own rapid rise, combined with rising Hindu nationalism and decolonization discussions, an aggressive mix. People see the West in decline and, on the one hand, envy it for its free way of life and at the same time pity it. At the same time, Indian society is still extremely strict on gender issues. Premarital relationships are still undesirable and marriages are extremely expensive. Young men without girlfriends have a hard time making contact with the opposite sex, are extremely uptight and sexually frustrated, consume Western porn and appear in mutually encouraging groups of men who become a danger to single girls and women. In addition, there is still a persistent misogynistic attitude in society. All of this seems to Westerners like an anachronism that they cannot cope with. Our emancipatory movements have led to widespread gender equality and respect for other cultures, accompanied by a decolonial guilty conscience that makes us vulnerable. We do not realize that the Internet, which has no borders, with its porn industry resulting from liberalism, has led to great desire for such freedoms and at the same time to contempt for Western values. Western women are seen as available, which is a huge misconception. Liberal excesses like the porn industry in the West are massively misunderstood as the sexual availability of women to sexually frustrated men. They do not understand the concept of equality and mutual respect between the sexes and western female pride and female self-confidence . The West must be careful that its values are not undermined and must still find a concept to defend these values internationally without instructing other cultures.

I hope this comment doesn't get moderated. First and foremost, I'm sorry you had a terrible experience. I would very much like to know what travel agency you used, cause others, if they choose to go, probably should avoid that travel agency. 

In terms of being sexually harassed online, months after the trip, that is disgusting, and I do condemn it, without exception. 

I would like to say however, that as with any country, travelling is a mixed bag and some have a good and others have a bad experience. Would I suggest travelling to India alone? Probably not. But I would say that for any country. And if I personally would do that, I'd be very careful about potential pitfalls (not casting any aspersions on the breadth of your research). I've had bad experiences on LA & Detroit cause I ended up in the wrong neighborhoods, and most of middle America, cause many people don't want a brown person around. My aunt got her passport stolen in Madrid. All this to say that experiences vary, and can be good or bad, but I'd be careful about generalizing that over a billion people. 

Personally, I've traveled to India with my wife (who's white and American), and she had no issues. This is also partially because I have a good knowledge of the country and it's cities and know what to avoid and when.

As for all the people calling out the horrific atrocities that have happened in India, that again, is not unique to that country. It is not difficult to find recent cases (2020 onwards) of heinous acts against women in the US. I don't think anyone would argue that there shouldn't be any travel to the US because of that. Let's not even talk about racially motivated crimes, police brutality, and shootings. Would one feel ill at ease travelling to the US for that? Before anyone calls it out as such, this is not whataboutism, cause I'm not saying the crimes are pardonable cause it happens everywhere. Rather, that we have to be consistent in our standards.

phoebe I am glad that you made it safely back home. It must be a truly traumatic experiences lecherous men lurking all around and feeling helpless in the sea of cold and crude patriarchally toxic men. That said, let me share my experiences of 25 years living in Delhi as a man from the North East of India, from the first day till the day I left even Indians who look different are not free from harassment of all kinds.

This toxic culture against women particularly women tourist is aggravated by the failure of the law enforcement agency. Why I say this? Of all the racially motivated murder, rape, molestation, harassment against North East women, not even one case had been investigated and justice delivered to victims. Prejudice and stereotypes about the North East are used to justify racial abuse and violence. Even Delhi Police in its 2008 guidelines to the North East People echoed this prejudice. Delhi Police guidelines advised North People to not cook and eat 'smelly' North East food. As a result since the last 2-3 decades lumpen elements and goons have picked up a culture of impunity, a conclusion that they can get away with anything done to the North East people in Delhi and other parts of India.

In 2013 a north East youth from Arunachal Pradesh was beaten to death in broad daylight in Amar Colony, South Delhi a place where I stayed as a college student in the early 1990s. Enough was enough, North East people protested and the UPA govt. set up a committee to examine the racial crisis. Before the committee was actually set up, ethnic civil society organisations were invited by the Home Ministry of the governement of India to New Delhi. A friend of mine who worked in a Naga organization in Kohima asked me to write a draft note to be presented to Mr. P. Chidambaram the then Home Minister. 

The draft note had five points but the key idea was 'Joint-Policing' to bridge the cultural gap. Delhi Police simply was understaffed and had little idea about the North East people and their culture. Police complaints by North East people barely made it to the prosecution stage due to the shoddy investigation. The department of SPUNER or (Special Police Unit Delhi Region) emerged from the South Delhi murder case and the draft note I mailed to friend who called back to say that all the five points had been submitted to the minister.

The point being, right thinking people in India need to ask the question whether it is time to have a new law and a special police force to address the harassment of women/tourists, foreigner or non-foreigner and the fallout of this crisis, India as hell-hole for foreign tourist. If the law is seen to be weak and the force lazy, people tend to think they can get away again and again after committing crimes. In the North East people case the law was seen to be weak and lazy. If the govt wants to genuinely ensure India as a safe tourist destination and project positive image globally, the lecherous and toxic lumpen culture must be firmly dealt with.

As an Indian, I want to express my concern. The reality is, safety is a major issue here  even many Indians feel afraid to step outside alone. There are bad elements around us everywhere, and many families are hesitant to let their loved ones go out alone.

If you‚Äôre planning to travel to India, please make sure you‚Äôre accompanied by two or more trusted people from different locations not from same location friends, especially in unfamiliar areas. In general, South India is considered safer compared to some parts of North India. People in the South are often more welcoming and protective toward newcomers.

Unfortunately, some regions in North India are known for scams, and not only do they target foreign tourists, but even visitors from South India are often scammed. This is a harsh reality we must acknowledge and work to change.

India has many beautiful and safe places, but travelers must remain cautious and informed. We hope to see the day when safety and hospitality are truly guaranteed for everyone.

I remember quite vividly one unsettling evening in Jaipur. While my boyfriend had stepped away to fetch us something to eat, I encountered three rather unruly men. They began harassing me, persistently asking where I was staying, who I was with, and, quite absurdly, demanding selfies. They seemed intoxicated and thoroughly inappropriate. I was utterly speechless!! Frozen in disbelief, scanning for my boyfriend amidst the crowd. When I finally spotted him, he gave me a reassuring smile, a subtle gesture to remain calm as he approached with purpose.

Now, do keep in mind, he‚Äôs a 6‚Äô2‚Äù boxer and wrestler, quite composed, yet no stranger to asserting boundaries. He addressed them with civility, asking them to kindly step back. However, one of them in a moment of misplaced bravado, attempted to place a hand on my shoulder. That‚Äôs when my boyfriend gently, but firmly, twisted the man‚Äôs wrist, just enough to bring him to his senses. The man apologized promptly, while the other two rather sheepishly wandered off and left him behind.

We returned to our seats, though I remained quite anxious for a time, half expecting them to reappear but thankfully, they did not. Let this serve as a gentle yet serious word of advice, always do your research, find a trusted local if necessary, and most certainly, it is highly recommended to bring someone along. Some men, regrettably, behave like ferals when left unchecked.

Hey Phoebe, I'm so glad I found your channel! This video caught my attention, because I traveled almost your exact itinerary in India in 2015, except in reverse (started in Goa, then Mumbai, then Udaipur, Jaipur, Agra and finally Delhi). Listening to your experience gave me chills. I was traveling in a small group of 3 women and 1 man. It never occurred to me how different that experience might have been had I been alone. Also I should say that half the trip was for a wedding of a friend who lives there, which was incredible and her family's hospitality was above and beyond. That made a big difference for my trip, but when I am asked whether I'd go back, I'm not sure these days. Everything you've said about the relentless selling I did experience 100%. We had some great guides, but after having nearly identical experiences in two cities (being taken to soooo many vendors as part of the tour), we didn't know how to feel. As an Indian, this video left me feeling deeply ashamed. I watched and listened with growing horror to this young lady narrate her harrowing ordeal while she was traveling in India. For whatever little it's worth, I want to apologise to this young woman, Phoebe, for her traumatic experience, and since there is nothing I can really do to mitigate the damage caused to her by the scoundrels she encountered on her tour, I thought I might leave a few suggestions for the future.

For all westerners traveling to India, please make note of the following:

1. If you are a woman, never ever be alone even for a second. It doesn't matter how old you are, or whether you are black or white or anything else. The predators don't discriminate when it comes to abuse, harassment and worse.

Always have some men near you who you feel will be there to stand with you in case you get accosted by predators. I'm sorry, I know that sounds misogynistic and patriarchal, but I'm just saying whatever occurs to me in the interests of safety. Your friends don't even have to be men of your own country, they could be men of any nationality, as long as you feel you can genuinely trust them with your safety and well-being.

2. The moment you feel unsafe, immediately pull out your phone and start taking a video of the people troubling you. That alone might be enough to intimidate any would-be harassers. It may or may not be enough, but it's a start, and it's still better than nothing. This one is actually tricky because I'm fully aware that in a frightening situation this would not occur to most people, as they are too shocked and frightened to respond at all, but if you are prepared for it beforehand, it might be easier to remember in times of crisis.

3. If possible, contact your country's embassy and high commission and seek help the moment something bad happens to you. It might also be a good idea to get in touch with the Indian Police, the government, the Ministry of Tourism etc. Record and document all conversations you have with local authorities, with names and designations if possible. They aren't really going to be very helpful, but again, it's still better than nothing at all, and you never know, someone might decide to step up and take action.

4. Making and sharing Youtube videos like this is an excellent idea. That's one reason I'm commenting here, so that it gets a little more reach. This raises awareness about the situation and ensures that similar or worse things don't happen to other people.

5. Do not, I repeat, DO NOT believe that you are overreacting or being unreasonable, or that you might have possibly done something to provoke this behaviour from other people. You are not responsible for how other people are making you feel. This is especially true of women.

6. If possible, name and shame the people who have harassed you. This one is especially important. It will warn others of who exactly to avoid and what to expect in case anyone runs into these people. Don't be embarassed to take the names of people who have troubled you if you know them, name the business and companies that have caused you distress if you can, and feel free to share any photos and videos you have of these people. It would also be an excellent idea to pass on this evidence to local authorities such as the police. Again, this may or may not be of use, but who knows? It's worth trying.

7. Don't let such experiences shake your confidence or self-esteem. It's normal to be upset and frightened and horrified and even traumatised, but if possible, don't let it harm your opinion of yourself and who you are.

That's all I have to say.

First of all, as Indian we apologize for what you had to experience in India. It should not have happened. There is no explanation or justification of what happened with you. However India is a beautiful country with awesome people. Obviously there are some bad elements in the society but they don‚Äôt represent the entire nation. I totally agree that it‚Äôs not entirely safe for solo travelers from foreign nations or even Indians themselves, but there are some basic rules of thumb you can follow to avoid more than 90% of such incidents:
1. Avoid booking hotels below $60 per day, as these are often not properly regulated. Given the large number of budget hotels in India due to the population, these cheaper options are usually unfairly managed and more prone to incidents  (we ourselves do not choose to stay at these places). The same applies to restaurants always check reviews on Google before visiting. Aim for restaurants rated $$ or higher on Google Reviews. These options are much less likely to encounter any such issues. Best is to choose well know hotel chains : Leela, Taj, Oberoi, Marriott. For budget travels Zostels are decent as well. Book your hotels online from known websites rather than through a travel guide. 
2. It‚Äôs best, best to just ask an Indian (your neighbor even if you barely know them) in whichever country you are in to help you with the travel. As an Indian, I can say we love to share our culture, and we are just waiting for you to ask us for help with your India travels. You can even ask that colleague/friend/neighbor of yours if they know someone in the cities you‚Äôre visiting who can guide you to good places, restaurants, and experiences.
3. Avoid booking through travel websites or tour agencies. This is one of the worst ways to travel in India, as most of these guides, as you mentioned, have commissions tied to specific hotels, restaurants, attractions or literally anywhere they take you to. 
4. Choose cities or areas within cities that are comparatively safer. For example, in my personal opinion (not to say other areas are unsafe), In Mumbai, areas from Bandra to Churchgate/Malabar Hill are the safest, and these are the areas where most of the good restaurants and places to visit are. So, you can book a hotel in any of these areas.
5. Use Uber for cabs, a bunch of other helpful apps like Blinkit (for a 10-15 minute delivery of literally anything even a TV at your place). 

6. Research thoroughly before your trip. If you are traveling with a decent or above-average budget, it will likely be safer and more comfortable than traveling on a tight budget.

57-year old American male here with three daughters roughly your age. I travel to India often so allow me to share some comments:

First, thank you for your authenticity. Speaking truth is key ‚Äî not just because you‚Äôre being of service to others, but you‚Äôre moving on from this experience in as healthy a way as possible. You seem brave, and that‚Äôs how you have to be when you‚Äôve had a terrible experience like this. 

Second, make no mistake. You WERE targeted. You were sexually harassed. And you were in very real danger at various moments you described. You did some things right. But if you don‚Äôt mind my saying ‚Äî you also did some things quite wrong.  

As you know, India has a well-documented issue with women being treated poorly. Catcalls all the way up to full-on sexual assault. It‚Äôs something I hope you were well aware of before traveling there. The fact that you responded to some of these incidents forcefully (shouting NO, etc) is important. Indian men do understand that and it ‚Äúcan‚Äù limit your potential for things getting worse. Good job there. However, there is no way ‚Äî noooo way I would recommend traveling alone as a woman. There is a very real cultural issue in India, and you experienced it first-hand. As you said, it‚Äôs not all men.   But as you saw, it only has to be a few men to make the trip perilous for western women traveling alone. And you dealt with a mob at one point. Frighteningly real.

The thing about traveling to India is that you have to have the mental mindset that EVERYTHING may/must change for you at a moment‚Äôs notice. You may get sick. You may get hurt. There may be environmental issues like excessive heat or monsoon rains. You have to be ready and willing to make changes immediately, including leaving quickly. I tell people all the time that you have to listen to your gut in India. More than in other places. If you‚Äôre not feeling safe ‚Äî you‚Äôre very likely not safe.   You have to prepare your brain for this internal conversation BEFORE getting on the airplane. You told yourself positive stories to keep yourself there, while your gut when sending you warning signals. Important ones, too. Truth is, you should have left ‚Äî or radically adjusted your plan ‚Äî as soon as you saw you were the lone traveler on this ‚Äútour.‚Äù Forget about the money. That‚Äôs gone. 

I‚Äôm so glad you arrived back mostly unharmed (sounds like you have some mental healing to go), and that hopefully you have learned a few things about India ‚Äî but also about yourself. You‚Äôre human. You seem a very positive person. And that worked against you here. 

India is a wonderful country filled with amazing people.   But they have their own unique issues just like every other country. India has a "Woman Issue."   You can travel India safely as a woman if you follow strict guidelines, one of which is to NEVER be alone as a western woman traveling extensively like you did. And even though it‚Äôs not a relaxing posture, you must have your radar up all the time. I have zero doubt that if you were with a group arranged by a reputable tour, you would have had an amazing time in this incredible place.

I'm sorry this happened to you.  But you've done a good thing posting this video.

India is an incredibly diverse country with a population of over 1.4 billion people, so it's important to understand that the experiences of a few may not reflect the reality for all. For many, especially in major cities or tourist spots, foreigners‚Äîparticularly Westerners‚Äîare often treated like celebrities, and the attention they receive can be overwhelming. It's not uncommon for people to approach for photos, follow them around, or act in ways that might seem intrusive.

However, it's essential to remember that this is often more about curiosity and admiration than any malicious intent. India is extremely vast, with every region offering a unique culture, language, and way of life. Things can change drastically from one area to the next‚Äîwhat might be true in one city may be entirely different just a few hours away. Unlike many other countries, where lifestyles tend to be more similar across the entire nation, India is a place where the culture and pace can shift in the blink of an eye.

With such a massive population and a rich diversity of cultures, regions, and languages, it's important to acknowledge that many people in India may have limited access to education or exposure to global norms. This can sometimes result in a lack of awareness about appropriate behavior or social etiquette, particularly in regard to foreigners or women. The notion of personal space, privacy, and what is considered respectful can vary greatly depending on where you are in India.

That said, understanding India takes more than just a quick  short travel‚Äîit requires a deeper engagement with its people and customs. It's important to plan your journey carefully, make friends and acquaintances who can guide you authentically, and always take the time to understand the places you visit by speaking to real locals. India is a land of contrasts and rich diversity, and the more you connect with it on a deeper level, the more rewarding your experience will be.

India can absolutely be safe for women, but like any place in the world, it‚Äôs important to be mindful of when, where, and how you navigate. With the right precautions, cultural awareness, and understanding, India offers a rich and rewarding experience for anyone willing to truly engage with its incredible variety and complexity.

It's all about perspective and being prepared. Just like any other country, being informed and taking the right steps can make your travels here comfortable, safe, and memorable.

India is a very tough place to travel around as tourist. I was there for 3 months backpacking when I was about 20 with friends, on the backpacker trail. This was in 1994 though. The sexual harassment aspect was not well publicised at that time and my sister was also travelling around India at the same time. I didn't hear any stories about sexual harassment from anyone at that time. We were well prepared mentally for how tough it was going to be in terms of scams, begging and generally aggressive people trying to get money from you. That said, it was an amazing trip. I liked the South and the North but not so much the middle section. 

The sexual harassment seems to have gotten worse and worse over the years and it seems from your experience that India now has a well deserved reputation for being perhaps the rape capital of the world.

I have traveled India from the Himalayas to Kaniyakumari for the past 25 years. Mostly I have traveled with groups and friends, and twice by myself. I have witnessed the moral downfall coming little by little. Now is an avalanche, out of control. My worst experiences have been in Agra, Jaipur and Delhi. Mostly scammers and very aggressive men. The state I have felt the most safe is Tamil Nadu. I have never experienced any sort of inappropriate behavior from anyone. Kerala is also quite safe. My advice to young solo female travelers: NEVER visit India alone if you don't know India very well. NEVER go alone unless you stay in very safe places with people you know. When I traveled twice by myself (2014 and 2023) I stayed in ashrams and spiritual communities where I know people, I know are safe places to stay and very peaceful and loving environment. For female travelers go to India only in groups from reputed and well known travel agencies.

I am an Indian man. While I feel ashamed of Phoebe‚Äôs experience, I am not surprised. This is the reason why India, with its vast heritage, ranks very low in tourist turn out. The reason for this phenomenon, as I understand is below:
1. Civility in public life has to be taught in schools and families. The school curriculum does not include it. Those families which do, bring up good citizen, others don‚Äôt. 
2. Poor policing and legal support. The administration never focussed on this. 
3. Poor tourist infrastructure. Even localities like Goa which do attract a fair share of tourists does not have facilities that assure to provide fine experience to tourists. 

For anyone who contemplate to visit India ( not sure if anyone who watches this video would), please consider the below:
1. Do not trust shady travel agents. Get connected to someone in India who will help you without commercial motive, say a mutual friend or his contact or someone. 
2. Let them fix up transportation for you, also a known person as guide. 
3. Avoid middle tier hotels. Go for international brands. Home stays for budget travellers only through known connections. 
4. Cities like Mumbai and Bangalore, where you can merge into the crowd will be safe. Same with tourist places which attract better quality Indian tourists.

I completely understand how you feel and can sense your helplessness. Please let me give you a hug! I have a similar experience to share. In 2018, my two best friends and I traveled to Thailand. The hotel we stayed at had a large pool, and we noticed a group of Indian men, about 8 to 9 of them, who would come downstairs to swim at around 11 AM and again at 4 to 5 PM every day. We were just three young girls, so to avoid them, on the fourth day, we deliberately went downstairs to use the pool at 8:30 AM. But, to our disbelief, just 30 minutes later, we saw these Indian men by the pool's edge (we could clearly see the pool from our room upstairs). It was a very large pool, yet they chose the entrance where we, the three girls, were, on the side, and ignored all the empty sunbeds on the opposite side. They placed their towels on the sunbeds and rocks next to our belongings, effectively surrounding us. The constant feeling of being watched made us very uncomfortable, so we decided to leave the pool. As we were leaving the water and getting out, it was very obvious that every Indian man was staring at us with strange looks, as if they were trying to strip off your swimsuit with their eyes. I assure you, I'm not mistaken about my feelings! When we were changing and leaving the hotel, one of my friends forgot her phone and had to go back. About ten minutes later, she called us to say that three of those Indian men, who should have been swimming, were following her. They came out the side door after us (the side door has a secluded path, but it's the most convenient way to the street). So, we had to abandon the convenient route and go back to the main road where there were more people. Guess what, those Indian men didn't take the side door but followed us to the main entrance instead. After we left the hotel through the main door, we went into a shop not far away and hid for a long time before leaving. Since then, I've had no good impression of Indian men at all! You're lucky that you didn't encounter anything worse; that in itself is a fortunate thing. I hope this won't haunt your life. Reflecting on our experience, we too feel the same sense of relief and gratitude for the luck that was with us.

Dear Phoebe! I am one of those solo female travellers who just got back from India. There are rules of solo travelling a Western woman should be aware of: 1. Dress local! preferably cheap and simple to stay invisible. In some places, it's best to cover your hair too! 2. Walk around with confidence, you can smile, joke and talk to people. But do NOT touch or shake hands with anyone as this is perceived as an invite. Namaste (folded hands) is enough. 3. Crowded tourist places - avoid eye contact, be determined and assertive, don't engage. 4. Never arrive at a new place late and/or when it's dark However, I mostly experienced travelling on pilgrimages to spiritual sites, and the crowd there might be a little different. You do get selfy requests though from men, women and sometimes even the whole family! I take it easy and most of the times say yes. One has to understand, that once you set your foot in an Asian country you have to forget what Privacy is. I find Indian people super friendly and kind. Though yes, they can annoy the life out of you! I am so so sorry about the experiences you had :(

My wife and I do general contracting in the states and took off a winter to take our tools and find an orphanage in India and do labor on the place and love the kids. While traveling looking for the right orphanage we went on a trek to the Triund. (Dharamsala) While trekking the road coming down off the mountain, we heard a loud group of men yelling out of their vehicle. So, I told my wife hide behind me and we luckily found a small crevasse in the rocks to shield her from view. One guy in the van got a glimpse of her and yelled," BLONDIE!!!" The van slide to a stop and all these guys started jumping out. All drunk and higher than a kite. I am 6' 2" 190 pounds and have done hard labor my whole life, barley any fat on my body. My thought was telling them we have been married for 30 years. My wife looks like she is 30. IF that didn't work, I had one option the first drunk guy reaching towards her goes 500 feet down off the cliff. It was a terrible dilemma Thank God another car came beeping their horn and they had to move their van down the hill. We exited the road went bush and luckily found our way down off the mountain. But low and behold they were waiting in the van at the end of the road. Luckily, we saw them and avoided them. The kids at the orphanage were GREAT! However, 2 months in we witnessed the smallest child have his head smashed hitting the back of his head into his food plate twice, for not eating and he was sick with the flu. We contacted the Vice Chairman at the time of the Bal Ashram Orphanage in Saliana and he said no kids are hit there. Went over his head to the Chairman an MD and he said the same thing, went to the editor of the local paper he said he would run a front-page story, and he said I wish you would have come to me I would tell you never go there they are thefts of donated money. Well, nothing happened, no story. So got on an overnight bus and traveled to see the S.P. , like our Attorney General. He sent his man in the Chief of Police at Saliana and no one talked. The cook said all the kids had been singled out and had the heck scared out of them if they talked. A couple of years later thank God the chief of Police's daughter said they got them out of there. The Chief and his family ware great people. BTW we were thrown out of the orphanage by a group of big guys into the darkness in the middle of the night onto an unlit street. An Indian guy we met let us stay at his house and two nights later the entry doorknob was turning, and we had it locked luckily. Guns are illegal in India, and he had given me a shotgun to defend my wife. If I would have killed some guys I would of went to jail there. We are NOT going back to India two winters from now doing philanthropy in Nepal, which has a good reputation for tourists. BEWARE OF INDIA a VERY VERY SMALL PORTION OF MEN THAT WANT TO SET UP A SITUATION WHICH "THEY BELIEVE CONDONES" A WOMEN ALEGELY ASKING FOR A GANG RAPE AND WE WERE SOMETIMES TREATED LIKE WE WERE A WALKING ATM MACHINE! However, we met many very spiritual people there and my own spirituality is now eastern it's just a shame that a few bad apples can be so dangerous to western women especially. I hope people don't consider "Please don't visit India, it is dangerous for women" like comments seriously, those types of messages are wrong to learn.

Instead we have 2 things to learn -
- India has a social problem of women harassment. India, and it's miscreants need to work on that, but this is a long term goal. The social fabric will not change overnight.
- Meanwhile, visitors should "Do proper research, know what to expect, and be prepared". These are factors that people can control themselves. If they do this, they can expect a far more welcoming and enjoyable experience and you will discover good side of India
Generally do not travel solo to states with low literacy rates. Literacy rate is a good predictor of safety

This is a shame. I was looking at your solo India videos, but it feels tainted now.  As someone from India: I'm sorry you had that experience, but you aren't the only one. To be frank, if any white woman asked me if it was okay to travel alone today in India, I would say no.  It can be safe, but it requires lots of research and contact with locals who have helped people who've been on that journey before, and it seems like you were unable to find the right people to make you feel comfortable consistently. That's the way it is at the moment, sadly. Wish you had received better advice before embarking on the trip.

Extremely disappointed for your experience. No one should be facing these situations.

Lesson other people SHOULD learn - Control factors, which they can control before visiting any unknown country to make sure they are able to absorb new cultures while minimizing chances of having a spoiled experience -

"Do proper research, know what to expect, and be prepared"

There can be many idiosyncrasies in how countries can be welcoming or unwelcoming at the same time.

For India, many visitors, including solo visitors too, have great experiences while traveling and interacting with locals, even when using public transport. It is "knowledge" / "skill" - to know what areas or activities can be safe, and where to expect the goons or scammers.

All this to say, I am definitely not writing your experience off and fully empathize. What people did with you is criminal and I hope you are able to overcome this. At the same time, for people who want to visit India, they are still fully welcome!

(Having a local friend to give some pro tips definitely helps, as locals are more aware when to be more aware, and always always always be CONFIDENT AND ASSERTIVE against scammers)

Good luck

I'm an Indian man who has lived in the US for 41 years. US is now my home. I'm outraged that you had to go through these experiences in India. Around the middle of the video, you made a point: You had a lot of bad experiences in India, that doesn't mean that all Indians are bad. I really like that. And that's the truth. Another example: there is a lot of crime in the US but you can't say that all Americans are criminals. My family and I just returned from India after a stay of more than 6 weeks. For two days, we stayed in an upscale hotel in Delhi. When we stepped out to get breakfast and tried to hail an autorickshaw to go to our favorite restaurant, a man approached us and told us that there a was great place (Handloom of India) near our restaurant and that the autorikshaw driver would be happy to take us after our meal there without extra charge. The driver said that was correct. The man also said that there were multiple stores near Handloom where we can shop. Excited, we agreed. We ate our breakfast and headed over to the Handloom. Alas, that was the only store there. We got in nonetheless thinking that we would look at some clothes. An hour and half later, we got out of there having spent 45,000 rupees on things that we didn't even want to buy in the first place. The autorikshaw driver was waiting patiently. He drove us back to our hotel. Right then we realized we got duped big time. The salespeople at the Handloom were aggressive and didn't take a no for an answer. My advice to non-Indians who travel to India:

If possible, don't travel alone. If you do, make sure that you don't stay in shady, cheap places. Spend at least $80 - $100 a night on hotels. Always shop at reputable stores. I don't know what to say about the harassment. Just walk away. Don't make eye contact. Indian men can be brutes. Some of them have no sense of personal space or common courtesy. But I would not lump everyone in the same box. Like you said, there are noble, decent, honorable men in India. Most Indian men are that way, in my opinion. That doesn't mean anything, though, for a tourist like you. Sorry.

Lastly, scammers exist everywhere. They come in different sizes and colors and styles.

It's really a class based thing. Don't go for tourist agency trying to cut corners and offering low priced packages. Always check out the review with negative sorted first. Given the bad exp you mention regarding Goa, it seems like the tour agency was sending you to the lower middle class/non mainstream accommodations and hang out spots to save money. The way it works is that those spots would be unsafe for most middle & upper class Indians themselves. It takes a lot of local experience to get a hang of this so please don't blame yourself. 

Traveling alone in India is not safe for Indians themselves (solo western women makes it 10-20x more scarier) if you're not able to sense out the different type of Indians you'll be encountering and the correct way to handle it. North India places also differ by city and even then, they're a total challenge if you venture into the low economic areas, which is where most of the times historical monuments are. The population density itself enabled the worst dregs to gravitate towards you while the more decent public won't be anywhere to found because they themselves are avoiding the same. It's such a big country with very high density & heavy inter-state migration, so you need to fight for you personal space in subtle ways. 

Please always go for more mainstream options when it comes to traveling to India or booking an agency.   

Hope you give it another a chance and have a better experience next time o/

Here is my true thoughts to share about my country (Pros and Cons and tips for better experience):

India is a great country like every other but as you shared the experience, there are dangerous areas and the thought of our people are still at a stage where it may be normal for us but for you is a threat.

Yes, the experience you had is unfortunately quite normal even to us Indians, though the scale of scam is definitely increased for foreigners.

And people like to take photos with a foreigner as there is this false prestige & pride developed due to social media.

We are a developing nation and it will take a lot more time for such mindset to change. And i can assure you. Change is happening. 

If you wish to travel and part of India, book through proper guide and make sure to spend money on a good tour package (India is cheap in terms of price but you will get quality as you spend more.) If traveling alone then plan ahead and plan accordingly (always be prepared for problems and take step by step action).

India is a safe country as long as you stay in areas where we Indians stay and not venture into unsafe areas we do not go.

Know that police is not 911 and emergency no. Varies from area to area. So keep a note.

Find a local Indian who you can trust online. We Indians will help always so reach out to us. 

There are many Indians like me who would help you have a comfortable stay and travel in each and every town. So dont be shy to reach us.

Avoid tourist trap areas. Delhi-Agra-Jaipur are beautiful places but have become tourist traps even to us Locals.

Have the following mindset ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è(most important)

1) Say ‚ÄúNO‚Äù STRONGLY. People will always wanna sell you and ask photos just say NO in a string voice and a few times.

2) Plan and do not alter from your plans unless avoidable. 

3) Bargain Bargain & Bargain. Its a must needed skill (if cant find a trustworthy local to help you with.) 

4) Everything has a tag called MRP which is the maximum price to sell stuff. If you buy something without MRP its either not mainstream, orginal or home made. So buy stuff with MRP (clothes, accessories and everything has MRP even food.)

5) Food is clean everywhere. But have medication as even we Indians get food poisoned in US/Europe or elsewhere due to change in food.


In summary, India is a safe country as long as you stay Strong, Plan and have a local for support.

(You guys can reach out to me for more questions and suggestions. I dont care if the questions are offensive as long as you wish to learn.)

High pressure sales is something you really have to watch out for on package tours. 

I found this out the hard way. I recently went on holiday to Cairo and some spots down the Nile. Like in this video, it was a package tour with flights, accommodation, transfers and activities sorted. One of my complaints before we left was that the itinerary was quite vague, often saying something like "explore the great pyramid before doing some cultural activities in Cairo". It turns out that "cultural activities" means that you will be taken to various shops and pressured into buying their products. It was really disappointing as 1) the reason we booked the package tour was to avoid these situations and 2) I thought we were going to be diving into the history and culture of Egypt. Instead it seemed to be an opportunity for our guide to have a break, while we were forced around a shop, shadowed by a salesman. These salesmen would use a lot of cheap tricks, for example if you stopped to look at something, they would put it behind the counter, "saving it for you", to pressure you into a purchase. They would not make the prices clear, especially for single items, often using the excuse that "they would come up with a price for ALL the items we were going to pick out, once we had finished shopping". And that was in proper shops. That's before we talk about the gauntlet of street salesmen that you were forced to walk through, coming into and out of attractions. 

I was "lucky" enough to experience this as part of a group tour, so at least the high pressure sales were spread over a group of people. I can only imagine what it was like as a solo traveller. Thank you Phoebe for bringing these practices to light!

Im a woman from India. I spent many years outside the country and returned to India during the pandemic and was locked down there. 

What you described about cards not working and leaving hotel room doors unlocked etc is bang on. Female staff in the hostel I stayed in Jaipur walked in on me using the universal key card. Once I did leave the country I couldnt trust for a long time that noone would enter my apartment. 

My family had a family gathering in a star hotel in Bangalore, and the hotel driver who drove me to the airport asked me if my father was a customer of mine and if i was using the cover of "father". We threatened to sue. The star hotel checked our passports and found we were indeed father and daughter and apologized - but it was horrific for us. The front desk staff at the hotel sobbed when she heard me sobbing.
I had a panic attack on the airplane and asked to remove covid masks and was moved inside the airplane and the airhostesses teared up.

The system is systemically exploitative and extractive. 

I had a travel insurance provider who was selling me travel insurance inform me there was no cover for sexually transmitted diseases after asking me if i traveled alone. He had to find a way to patronize me while selling me a product. 

I was asked to cook by a hotel owner and to serve him water during the peak of the pandemic. I was trapped with them and they took the opportunity to humble me. 
I was paying full price at his hotel where he had no other guests because of the pandemic. Im a woman with a very respectable financial standing and this was very jarring experience. Since they controlled food during the pandemic if i didnt pander to their expectations, they would not give me food. I remember being willing to tip people generously just to stop hassling me. I had to pay the price for being a woman that had a level of financial affluence without paying the toll for violating their social norms. 

The government official who administered my vaccine misbehaved with me. I could do nothing without having an instance of SH and it affected me to my very core. There's this dull feeling of resignation when the body goes into survival mode when this happens over and over.

I had a landlord in one of those apartments who was my protector. He made some passes, but very respectfully and told me as I left that I should never return without a male figure. I thanked him because he had looked out for me. 

It was an 8 month long nightmare. My family had left the country but I had an Indian passport and couldnt leave with much ease. I also lost emotional strength and faculties during that stressful phase. 

You made an effort not to hurt people's sentiments while being in excruciating pain yourself. I appreciate it but that takes a heavy emotional toll. Truth is, that is a culture which coddles its men. There should be economic consequences, these are natural consequences.

I eventually purchased a Privilege visa and guaranteed that I would always have another option I could reliably fall back on if there were yet another unforeseen crisis. 
I remember thinking to myself, well death is inevitable but id like to age and pass in a society where I do not feel such an intense alienation towards, not to mention feeling hunted, intruded upon and watched. It has definitely impacted how I relate with men, both from my culture and others.

In Himachal Pradesh, they would matter of fact open my Amazon packages and refuse to pick up my garbage. 

What you said about the sense of relief when you left resonated. I had to sleep for four months and could hardly work, so I requested time off and my clients understood. It took me 14 months to stop being worried that someone would enter my apartment in the next country I now live in. When i shared my concerns in this new country, people are simply amazed that I would even have such a concern. 

Ive been reflecting on my sense of identity, belonging and self worth as it pertains to the country I was born in. 
I question if unconditional loyalty is owed to any system one may belong to where one had no choice. I will change my passport for cathartic reasons. I also plan to lobby for extending refugee visas for Indian minority women so more women who want to live peaceful lives outside can have options availavle to them.

It is an incredible country with a powerful past but I should not have to carry such a heavy weight to accommodate a society I find harder and harder to understand. That the burden should be on you, or on me to communicate effectively while being traumatized and violated is a tad bit excessive.

A tip to solo women travelling to India:

It is better to avoid the locations which are famous with local tourists, Jaipur, Agra, Goa. These cities are very very famous with locals. Now these local tourists might be travelling for the first time in their life. They might have never seen any foreigners and they might find you fascinating and would want to click pictures with you. 

To avoid this situation, go to tourist hubs which gets the civilised crowd, the crowd which is well travelled.


Offbeat locations are much better for tourists, because they get the civilised Indian crowd. So instead of Goa maybe you can go to Gokarna, instead of Jaipur you can go to Udaipur or Jodhpur, instead of Haridwar go to Rishikesh. The lesser the number of local tourists the better the experience is going to be.

If you do visit local tourist hub. Try to find areas which are famous with foreigners and stay there. You can ask on any forum. In Goa you have Arambol famous with foreigners.

Hey Phoebe, sorry to hear about your experience in India. As an Indian that grew up in the US, I would make some suggestions. 

Is traveling solo as a female safe in India? Yes & No. You have to do it the right way. Spend the extra money and stay in a proper five star hotel, Oberoi, Taj, Leela, ITC etc. Then book a proper guide through the hotel that they regularly use, not some local. This way, you can tell the guide exactly what you want and what you want to avoid, and they will follow your instructions to the letter. 

Last thing, In India, you have to be rude to a certain extent. You have to keep blinders on and keep walking, pretend you didn‚Äôt hear anything when someone asks you a question. @travelforphoebe Hai Love, I am really sorry about things which you had to go through. I would like to shed some light and give some pointers to other solo travellers. 

See India is a beautiful place, the tradition, the customs etc but travellers have to understand that this is a country which is still recovering from the shackles of independence, People didn't had much experience to see outside world, for them you are standing out like a Alien or a Deer in headlight. 

If you are vary of people or are a introvert India is not for you. There arw 140 billion people living there.

Now what happens is Most of tourist fall for the Golden triangle trap, they land in Delhi (worst city safety wise even for locals) then there are scammers on every street there because everyone is hustling. Try to spend minimum time there, there is nothing to see much in Delhi. 

Then they go to other tourist trap of Jaipur etc where most of population is not literate. Men and women both are struggling to make ends meet, they have not seen outside world much, so when girls come and visit they get curious. 

Now the mentality of those 95 percent men is not to harm you but to take picture with you to show to their friends or family that they have taken a picture with a white person, it doesn't matter if you are a white male or female they will take pictures with both. 

If you are not comfortable you have to be assertive, it is always advisable to visit some posh places or make some friends prior to visiting india as india is not for beginners. 

Now the most important mistake people do is they just read about these places and go and ignore the best places which they ahould have went like Leh Ladakh, Himachal, Northeast Assam, sikkim, Shimla, j&k, Kerala. The people you will find in these places are more friendly and well accustomed. 

You ahould always book a reputed company for tours and travels, something high end, they take care of all your safety and experience. 

Traveling in india is a experience and it can be Bad or good depending upon how we make it. 

It is always advisable if you are visiting India be prepared to be looked upon, people will approach you out of curiosity, many times 95 percent as I mention they would like to click pictures, aomw might even enjoy the attention and some will not. 

You have to be assertive and maintain distance, always keep a driver accompanied with you if you are alone. 

Even indian people from other cities face same problem, always vary of scams and those trying to take you to shops to buy things. There is a fixed percentage of sales tied. Hence try to avoid such guides and book guides from online well reputed company, they will take care of you. 

I am again sorry for things you had to go through and hope you dont think bad of all Indians and possibly will come back and see other side of india.

India itself is a experience, you just have to find it, as a solo girl traveller it is hard to travel but have to pick the right experience. Avoid scam places. 

Goa is also now full of foreigners, many practically living there, people are SA there but the police is equally stringent there, you can just file a complain and they take care of things. Catcalling and stuff can happen visiting many places even in West, happens to my friends travelling in London. So no place is safer for solo women travellers, you just have to take self precautions and rely more on your inner instincts. 

I would suggest people who are looking to travel to india is look beyond the tourist trap, go for places mentioned above in my comment and see the difference. 

Also those places are natural and clean and serene. Hope it helps clear few things. üòä
