That is how many Indian men in India are and unfortunately reflects on the culture .. a total shame! not too uncommon for Indian women to experience similar, though things get more out of control when a beautiful white girl or boy walks their neighborhoods.. obsession with white people is still something crazy there. While I'm not from India, I've visited South India and people tell me that its relatively better / safer there - less harassment. The thing you noticed about Indians having a 'pack mentality' is quite common.. when one attacks someone, the rest jump in and join.

A few things I've learned while visiting India - 

1) Always better to travel in a group
2) Stay in mid-top tier hotels - they often have better security, and are faster and better when responding to your needs
3) When traveling in trains, choose first class, or better.. do not travel in a lower class.
4) Taking a rickshaw is fine in places where traffic is very light, like in rural areas. But in cities where traffic is dense, take taxi / cab / Uber / etc.. this goes back to your safety.. plus you will inhale less toxic fumes.
5) Be careful of ALL 'holy men/women'.. many are scammers or simply just out to get money or sex from those they prey upon... in the name of God. 

The big question is, what will President Modi do in his third term to protect tourists? Unfortunately, till today India is referred to as the 'rape capital' of the world.. by foreigners / outsiders.. there's a reason for that. Foreigners should generally feel safe traveling anywhere in India without being harassed or feeling unsafe.

My experiences as a native Indian: (note: The average north indian is the most hospitable person you can get and are really friendly and helpful. So not dissing the average person. I may not be the most adventurous person)

The rest of India is simply more calm and far less overwhelming than the North. The cities are less populated than the north. The ppl are a lot less aggressive and pushy. The scams are lesser than the north (not zero. There's a lot here too. Just lesser). This is something my north indian peers say too. 

Our family's personal experience in Rajasthan: 
We stayed at reputed 4 star hotels throughout the trip. The staff at the hotels were very good. The forts are epic. The Udaipur cruise was awesome. The Rajasthani food is good. 

The problems: We Indians know the art of bargaining and knowing when to spot scams like Pashmina etc etc. We know that tourism guys like cab drivers can be pushy. But even for us it was getting overwhelming. 

We hired a driver via the hotel from Jodhpur to Jaipur. He was nice at first, but highly aggressive later. He wasn't listening to our parents request to drive calmly. His conduct at petrol stations was shady as heck. We were relieved when we reached Jaipur. The agency associated with the Jodhpur hotel that gave the driver apologized and gave us other drivers for Jaipur. The hotel was wonderful. But the first Jaipur driver was highly pushy. He wasn't wanting us to go to Bapu Bazaar which is a beautiful Bazaar. He was pushing us to go to a mall which we weren't interested. We had to be assertive. 

The 2nd driver wasn't pushy but he was unfriendly. 

At Udaipur, the drivers were quite aggressive. This sullied our trip there a bit. It gave a bitter taste. The mistake we made: hiring drivers at the airport in Udaipur, and continuing with the agency from Jodhpur. 

My tips when visiting India: 

Stay at reputed hotel chains like Taj, Ibis, Fortune etc. Don't go to unknown hotels. 

Use guides/drivers from the hotels. Don't use unknown agencies. Even though they maybe more expensive, it helps

Do thorough research. Put your foot down when the driver doesn't want to take you to places you want to visit. Don't let the drivers  dictate how the trip should go. Inform the hotels if you feel uncomfortable. 

Don't fall for scams. If you want to do shopping, shop at places you've researched and feel comfortable. 

Don't indulge in too many conversations outside of the travel related stuff. It can easily get dicey. 

Don't allow auto/cab guys to bring others into the vehicle. 

Be vigilant throughout the journey. Observe the drivers conduct. Walk out if unsafe after pending money settlements. 

Keep cash. It helps. Also keep food poisoning medicines ready.

Here are the top 10 etiquette tips specifically for Indians traveling abroad. Following these points will ensure respectful, positive interactions and help avoid common cultural misunderstandings.

## Top 10 Etiquette for Indians Abroad

1. **Speak Softly in Public:** Avoid shouting and loud group conversations, especially in closed spaces like trains, airports, and restaurants. Keep mobile phone calls discreet
2. **Respect Local Rules and Queues:** Always queue up, wait for your turn, and avoid pushing. Follow all posted rules at tourist sites and public spaces
3. **Dress Modestly:**  Follow local dress codes, especially at religious sites and conservative countries. When in doubt, choose modest clothing
4. **Treat Accommodations with Care:** Respect hotels, Airbnbs, and public amenities as you would your home; don‚Äôt litter or damage property
5. **Don‚Äôt Insist on Indian Food or Criticize Local Cuisine:** Be open to trying local foods; avoid making negative remarks about the local cuisine. Respect hosts' hospitality
6. **Learn Basic Local Phrases:** Knowing a few words like ‚Äúhello‚Äù or ‚Äúthank you‚Äù in the local language is appreciated and shows respect for the culture
7. **Limit Public Displays of Affection:** Many countries consider hugging or kissing in public inappropriate‚Äîobserve local customs before engaging in such behavior
8. **No Littering:** Always dispose of waste properly, follow recycling or waste classification if required, and keep surroundings clean
9. **Don‚Äôt Compare or Act Superior:** Avoid claiming that things are better in India or acting condescending. Respect local traditions and be a humble guest
10. **Respect Photography Rules:** Always ask before taking photos of people or sensitive places. Look out for no-photography signs at landmarks and holy sites

I am Indian, living in the UK for the past 17 years, and have travelled to nearly 30 countries. What I want to share is not criticism, but reflection‚Äîbecause improvement starts with small things.

Take flights, for example. The moment a plane lands, why is there a rush to get out? Seat numbers exist for a reason. Wait your turn. If you‚Äôre in a genuine hurry, speak to the cabin crew. Rushing past others doesn‚Äôt make you smarter, it just shows impatience.

As middle-class spending rises, it doesn‚Äôt mean we own the world. Respect for others should grow along with our success. If you can‚Äôt be kind, at least be quiet and follow basic order.

A few basics we often forget:

Don‚Äôt play videos loudly in public. Use headphones.

Don‚Äôt break into loud singing or dancing anywhere you feel like. Every country has its own culture‚Äîrespect it instead of trying to impose ours.

Parents, when you go to your child‚Äôs school, don‚Äôt show up in chappals or pyjamas. You don‚Äôt need to be rich to dress decently‚Äîyou just need mindfulness.‚Äî

The ‚Äúchalta hai‚Äù attitude or ‚Äúhum kisi se kam nahi‚Äù pride is meaningless unless it shows in our actions.

I‚Äôll share a real example. In Prague earlier this year, I saw an Indian tourist quietly take the restaurant menu away without even asking the staff. Why? That small act leaves a big impression‚Äîon the restaurant, on other diners, and on how the world perceives us.

We are educated. We are financially doing well. Let‚Äôs reflect that dignity not just in words but in behaviour. Live normally, respect others‚Äô spaces and cultures, and avoid forcing our own beliefs where they don‚Äôt belong.

Everything else falls into place when we learn patience and respect.

There is a strong need to incorporate education on hygiene, cleanliness, and civic responsibility into the Indian school curriculum starting from the elementary level. This education should go beyond theory and include hands-on activities such as organizing village and neighborhood clean-up drives at least once every semester. These practical sessions will help instill a sense of responsibility, community ownership, and respect for public spaces among students from a young age.

In addition, the government must take proactive steps to support and sustain such efforts. This includes allocating sufficient funds, improving sanitation infrastructure, ensuring access to clean water and waste disposal systems, and launching large-scale awareness campaigns to educate the public about the health and societal benefits of cleanliness. Collaborative efforts between schools, local governments, NGOs, and communities will be essential in transforming these values into everyday habits and ensuring a cleaner, healthier environment for future generations.

As an Indian citizen, I feel our civic sense needs serious improvement.
Many young people in India still lack awareness of proper public behavior.

Common issues include:
Speaking loudly in public transport
 Throwing waste on the streets
Staring at women
Poor table manners in public
Ignoring hygiene and etiquette

These habits create a bad impression at home and abroad.
The government should introduce hygiene and civic behavior courses from primary school.
This will help children build good habits early.
Before granting visiting visas, travelers could also attend a short orientation on etiquette and cultural sensitivity.
This will prepare Indians to represent the country with dignity.

China faced a similar problem 15 years ago.
They solved it with strict rules and mandatory training.
India can learn from that example.

Improving civic sense will make life better in India.
It will also earn Indians more respect worldwide.

For example, in the West there are homeless people who urinate in public, go years without bathing, and struggle with severe mental health issues. Just got back from a week-long trip to Zermatt, Switzerland‚Äîand I couldn‚Äôt agree with you more! A few highlights from my experience:

1). The train incident: There was an Indian couple on the train, both on separate video calls with their families back in India. It cannot be said that all communities in the world are perfect, as both good and bad are inherent to human nature. However, some societies maintain a higher standard than others in their behavior towards their surroundings, nature, and laws.
A community's civic sense is primarily shaped by the government's laws, regulations, citizen rights awareness, schools, and family. The most important of these is the direction provided by the government. Many developed nations cultivate excellent civic sense in their citizens from a young age through curricula and schools.
Unfortunately, the people of India did not have this fortune. Since independence, those who governed India did not pay enough attention to such matters. Rulers chosen by the people based on religion, caste, and politics did not include subjects like civic sense in the curriculum. As a result, when Indians travel abroad, they often lack a proper understanding of how to behave in public places and beaches, or how to do things cleanly.
Due to the incompetence of such governments, Indians sometimes find themselves disliked by citizens of other countries when they travel abroad. In conclusion, the civic sense of a nation's people is shaped by the laws created by the government they vote into power and the curricula in schools.

A very Good Video. 
There seems to be a deeper issue on the Indian side. Instead of merely reacting to the videos circulating worldwide, one should ask why such content is being created in the first place. The answer does not lie in food, appearance, or scent, but rather in certain behaviors that have left people feeling offended. What many perceive as cultural ridicule and targeted mockery is, in fact, a form of underlying aggression.
One possible reason could be an overt display of nationalism that often comes across as abrasive something we have witnessed in how some Indians publicly confront citizens of Nepal, Bangladesh, and Pakistan. Another contributing factor may be the repeated negative experiences of tourists; countless recent videos depict visitors being overcharged or scammed by auto drivers, vendors, or local businesses.
This growing pattern has not only strained relationships with neighboring countries but is now shaping global perceptions as well. Instead of dismissing the criticism, it is important to ask why such resentment exists and, more importantly, how it can be addressed constructively.

Another thing that needs to be said: how are people so sure that all those ‚Äúviral clips‚Äù are even Indians? Yes, a few faces might be moderately known, but let‚Äôs be honest‚ÄîSouth Asians from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and Nepal often look very similar. It‚Äôs easy for anyone to label a random video as ‚ÄúIndian‚Äù just to push a narrative. And let‚Äôs not forget, there are always groups around the world whose only job is to defame India and Indians, sometimes even paid to do so.

Of course, I am not saying that none of those clips feature Indians‚Äîsome definitely do. But it is also true that our neighbors have been caught doing the same things, and the blame instantly gets put on India. This selective targeting shows the bias clearly.

So the bigger question is not just about hygiene or culture‚Äîit‚Äôs about how India is being unfairly singled out at a time when the country is growing rapidly, asserting itself globally, and refusing to be anyone‚Äôs follower. That‚Äôs why stereotypes get recycled again and again, regardless of the facts.

Many foreigners label Indians with stereotypes like ‚Äúdirty,‚Äù ‚Äúunhygienic,‚Äù or ‚Äúnot using deodorant.‚Äù Some Americans, British people, and even African guys have repeated these claims, and as Slay Point mentioned, a few viral videos of individuals doing questionable things often fuel this perception. But I respectfully disagree with this one-sided reasoning.

The bigger reality is that much of this criticism comes from **jealousy and insecurity** about India‚Äôs rapid rise on the global stage. India is no longer the underdog‚Äîit is one of the world‚Äôs fastest-growing economies, a hub of intelligent and highly educated professionals who are excelling in technology, medicine, research, and leadership roles across the globe. From Silicon Valley to the UN, Indians are everywhere, contributing with skill and brilliance.

And let‚Äôs not ignore the political angle. Leaders like PM Modi and S. Jaishankar have shown the world that India is **confident, self-reliant, and unwilling to bow down** just to please Western powers. This firm stance‚Äîdeciding what‚Äôs best for India through our own lens while also respecting others‚Äîmakes certain countries uncomfortable. When India asserts its independence, those used to dictating terms feel threatened.

And here‚Äôs the irony: those lecturing us on hygiene often don‚Äôt bathe daily themselves‚Äîsometimes due to cold weather, scarcity of water, or simply habit. Many rely on tissues instead of water, which in our culture is considered incomplete cleaning. Still, we never mock them. Instead, we welcome everyone with folded hands, because in India we believe in Atithi Devo Bhava (Guest is God) and Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam (The world is one family).

So before pointing fingers at India, maybe it‚Äôs time people look honestly at their own practices. India is not perfect, but it is strong, proud, and rising‚Äîand no stereotype can change that.

So yes, while a few bad viral clips might exist, reducing an entire nation of 1.4 billion people to unhygienic stereotypes is unfair and intellectually lazy. The real reason behind this narrative is that a rising India is no longer ‚Äúobedient‚Äù but equal‚Äîand that shift unsettles many.

The theory of Terror attack based on the Qualitative Sound Intensity and the Debris generated by the explosion up to a large distance is unfounded because :
1-If it was a planned Terror Attack, the car would have been parked in some crowded area much before the explosion and the driver would have got down to move to safe place.
2- Attributing it to a Suicide Attack is a headless assumption because the Suicide attack is always targeted attack when there is no alternative.
3-The Vehicle was moving slowly is an adequate proof of  distracted Fuel Air Ratio in the Engine  implying that there was spontaneous leakage of CNG inside the vehicle which created . Vapor Cloud Explosive (VCE) mixture of a large volume of unignited gas inside the vehicle and the  explosion occurred due to ignition when the  engine stopped and was switched on to  restart by the driver and the flammable vapor cloud (VCE) exploded  generating  Shock Waves causing  significant damage and injuries over a wide radius. 

4- The explosion from CNG ignition if the leaked gas has filled the vehicle space could created Shock Waves generating pressure of thousands of atmosphere which may produce very high pitch sound and shatter anything on its way converting it to debris particularly if the CNG Cylinder had melted locally and then blasted.
5-In a 33/11 KV OCB in Gorakhpur in 1998 when the cooling oil cylinder locally melted due to short circuit it exploded producing shock waves which shattered the Building walls and Doors and Windows of another building were thrown out at some 50 meter away from the cylinder even though the cylinder contained cooling oil not  CNG  being 1000 time  more explosive than oil.
6-The Investigating team seems to be politically guided to term it a Terror Attack as it was prejudiced to lodge FIR under UAPA prior to conclusion of the cause of explosion . 
7- The correct reason could be determined only after ascertaining the physical status of the CNG cylinder if the vehicle was CNG operated which has not been done so far

After watching travel videos showcasing beautiful countries, I always thought, "Wow, how gorgeous they look! I need to experience this." But today, I saw a video about Kerala, India, and it made me realize something important. I've been to the same places shown in the video, but my experience was completely different. It hit me that the quality of a travel experience isn't just about the destination‚Äîit's about how much money you can spend. With enough money, even a place like India can look spectacular. For example, the resort featured in the video costs about a month's salary for the average Indian. In the end, it all boils down to how much you can afford to spend. The more money you have, the more beautiful and luxurious your trip will be. Also STOP editing the footage to make it look beautiful.

India is a vast landmass. The people of Indian Union do not have a common culture, a common language, a common cuisine or a similarity in appearance. Indian Union has 28 states and 8 union territories. Each of them has the same size and population similar to a European country. They all have their own language, culture, cuisine and lifestyle.
 Some of them are snow-capped mountains, some are coastal, some are deserts, some are swamps, some are rainforests, there are places where it never rains, but India also has the rainiest region in the world.
As a female tourist, dare to travel to India, admiring! Take care!

To be honest when I arrived in Kerala and saw the ‚ÄúGod‚Äôs own Country‚Äù catch phrase from its tourism department, I kind of rolled my eyes. But somewhere along my trip, as I took in the natural beauty and the love from its people, I gradually realized I didn‚Äôt even want to leave that place. It truly was God‚Äôs own country. It had a way of making everyone feel at home. I still feel like I belong there and I am a malayali (although I don‚Äôt speak the language). One of most beautiful places I‚Äôve ever been and that‚Äôs not just the nature, but people too.

As someone who has travelled to Europe and South East Asia - the latter especially places like Kerala (India in general) are so much welcoming than places like Italy or France where they frown upon foreigners (especially Americans). In contrast Malayalis (that‚Äôs what people from Kerala call themselves) are so thrilled to show you around. Every local I‚Äôve met have been super friendly and helpful. Whenever I‚Äôve been to Europe all I get is contempt for America and some pretentious bs about how everything there is more authentic and better than the rest of the world. In India I felt people appreciate me as a tourist more, they welcome your questions and accept you to a degree that you can‚Äôt even remotely experience in France / Italy.

I know u many be having doubts about safety and cleanliness. 
A tip from my part -
1. Wear what the locals are wearing. It will give u a whole different respect and acceptance. Kurtas are the best choice as they are accepted throught out.
If not wear jeans and shirts/tops - try avoiding too revealing ones. Not saying ppl are bad . But many might feel more comfortable if u wear things that they have been used to seeing
2. India has rich ppl , middle class and poor ppl and that separation is evident. Go where the middle class go.. That would be economical and healthy too.
3. Dont trust everyone. And politely deny ppl asking for selfies
4. Police are very particular about safety of foreigners.
5. Most ppl are very welcoming and ready to help. Just avoid the ones that u are doubtful about. If u have doubts or need help its best to ask a family group or a college group than  single individuals. If u feel unsafe stay close to family groups and college groups
6. Avoid cheap hotels. Go for middle class ones

Dude just avoid Delhi and its surroundings. Like a moth to the light, all the bad people are there. South India - Kerala and Tamil Nadu are backpack heavens and are safe and truly traditional. Manali ( mini Israel and weed culture & spiritual  ), Dharamshala ( Dalai Lama is here hiding) are lovely places to chill out nomadic for a while. State of Uttarakhand and Sikkim are perfect for month long stay and spiritual too. North East - Arunachal Pradesh and Meghalaya are pristine and calm. Perfect for relaxing but it's very cold now and you would definitely need to plan ahead. Transportation is bad and it's all mountains. Avoid Kolkata or West Bengal state. They are lost cause. No Odisha or middle of India or the east side. Pondicherry is fine with the French culture.  Uttar Pradesh is where most of the spiritual stuff is from. State of 246 million people !!!! Varanasi ( cremation grounds ) Mathura (Krishna stuff).  The state of Bihar with 13 million people (Buddha was here 2000 years ago) is where you can see true poverty and population. Hey Elena! Depending on where you are in the city, it's not necessary to dress that modestly. If you're not vising the older parts of the city ( I can only talk about Delhi because i live here) you'll be fine ditching the tank top underneath your blouses, or maybe wearing just the tank top. Try avoiding foods with any raw vegetables in it, as that will help avoid the upset stomach. You should also get a big scarf, which will come in useful if you plan on visiting temples. Make sure it's light and airy. 
Hope you have a great time here!

Hey Elena! Indian girl here
Few tips: use Uber or ola(Indian version of Uber) and don't use local cabs cause they might charge you extravagantly. Stay hydrated cause heat strokes are very common here. And buy only packaged water bottles like bisleri, aquafina, kinley. Ask for those in restaurants instead of drinking the water they serve you(even if they claim it's RO). Your immune system isn't adapted to the weather and water so try not to eat uncooked food like chaats. If you are in Delhi or any of the other northern states then please be cautious of your surroundings. Keep everything locked at all times. If you're having trouble navigating or feel uncomfortable, look for women(preferably younger ones who're usually fluent in English). If you feel uncomfortable at any point, then speak out, people will help you out.
Hope you have a wonderful time here! It really is quite safe nowadays but since you are well dressed and (hate to say it) white, people will think that you have a lot of money to spare and ask for ridiculous amounts of money. Otherwise I'm sure you're gonna love it here!

I hitch hiked in the northern part of India back in October. It was such a cool experience. It was so freeing and opened my eyes to what traveling can really be like. 

Long story short, I met a few guys in a hostel my first day in Delhi, and ended up spending a few weeks traveling with them. We went to Leh, Ladakh (northern India) and hitched a ride from there to Diskit. There were pretty insane roads up there: picture unpaved, rocky, and exposed cliffs. Went over a very high mountain pass at nearly 18000 feet (5480m). We had to split off into two hitched rides because it was hard as a group of 3 to get a lift. Our driver in the car I rode in was so kind and refused money from us. We even stopped for some hand-made noodles in the most delicious thukpa soup on the way and tried butter tea. They had a sweet dog in the car and I had to sit in the middle seat so the dog could have the window seat üòÇ

Tried to hitch a ride a few days later up to Turtuk, but after spending 4 hours trying to hitch a ride and getting caught in a sand storm, we ended up having to get a taxi. The taxi driver was over an hour late lol. It was a crazy day. 

Hitch hiking is awesome. Be careful especially if you‚Äôre a woman! I felt safe because I was traveling with two men, but otherwise *personally* I wouldn‚Äôt have hitch hiked. But that‚Äôs just me :)
Amazing people visiting Amazing Places with Amazing Hearts

British rule in the Indian subcontinent, affected social development, public infrastructure, and perceptions of ‚Äúcivility.‚Äù
It‚Äôs true that before colonial rule, the subcontinent had highly developed urban planning and hygiene systems in many periods of history ‚Äî for example:


The Indus Valley Civilization (Harappa and Mohenjo-daro) had advanced drainage systems and public baths over 4,000 years ago.


Ancient and medieval Indian cities often emphasized water management, waste disposal, and sanitation, with sophisticated tank and canal systems.


When the British colonized India, their policies prioritized resource extraction and trade advantages for Britain rather than the welfare of local populations. Infrastructure was often designed to serve British administrative and commercial interests (like railways for moving raw materials), not local health or sanitation. By the time they left in 1947, much of the subcontinent‚Äôs economy and infrastructure had been reoriented around colonial needs ‚Äî and many indigenous systems of civic management and education had deteriorated or been replaced.
The notion that ‚ÄúEurope is civilized‚Äù and colonized peoples are not was itself part of the colonial narrative ‚Äî a way to justify imperial rule. Modern historians increasingly challenge that idea, recognizing that the British Empire left deep social and economic scars while appropriating local knowledge and wealth.

If u want beef , go to Northeast states like Mizoram, Nagaland, Manipur, don't know if beef is easily available in Assam. You can get beef in Kolkata, Hyderabad & many places in Kerala & may be in Goa as well. But you may not get beef sandwiches at all anywhere in India & it sounds crazy. You will find beef curries & other items made from beef in the cities or states that I have named above. You may or may not find cooked Bacon at all in any burgers but I did find a shop in New Delhi which had raw Bacons & pork available but I didn't buy them as I was only visiting New Delhi & I didn't have the means to cook. Second place is Indonesian Citarum ‚Äì its lead content is over 1,000 times higher than the US Environmental Protection Agency standard for drinking water. Water from the Ganges has been linked to dysentery, cholera, hepatitis, and severe diarrhea, which remains one of the leading causes of death among children in India. But pollution, dams and removal of too much water (mostly for agriculture) have affected the flow and health of this vital river. One of the river's most at-risk animals is the Ganges river dolphin. The Ganga today is facing formidable pollution pressures, along with the attendant threats to its biodiversity and environmental sustainability.

When a person dies, physical and mental structure disappears but the soul stays on and tries to find another womb. After death, the energetic structure takes a few days to completely leave the being(that is why you see some processes like fingernails growing even for the dead body). WHAT IS SPECIAL ABOUT BEING A HINDU (Sanatana Dharma)?

Written by Indian Journalist having French roots - Fran√ßois Gautier

1) Believe in God ! - Aastik - Accepted 
2) Don't believe in God ! - You're accepted as Nastik
3) You want to worship idols - please go ahead. You are a murti pujak.
4) You dont want to worship idols - no problem. You can focus on Nirguna Brahman-shapeless, formless ,infinite, without beginning or end(nirvikalpa brahama)
5) You want to criticise something in our religion. Come forward. We are logical. Nyaya, Tarka etc. are core Hindu schools.
6) You want to accept beliefs as it is. Most welcome. Please go ahead with it.
7) You want to start your journey by reading Bhagvad Gita - Sure !
8) You want to start your journey by reading Upanishads - Go ahead.
9) You want to start your journey by reading Purana - Be my guest.
10) You just don't like reading Puranas or other books. No problem my dear. Go by Bhakti tradition . ( bhakti- devotion)
11) You don't like idea of Bhakti ! No problem. Do your Karma. Be a karmayogi.
12) You want to enjoy life. Very good. No problem at all. This is Charvaka Philosophy.
13) You want to abstain from all the enjoyment of life & find God - jai ho ! Be a Sadhu, an ascetic !
14) You don't like the concept of God. You believe in Nature only - Welcome. (Trees are our friends and Prakriti or nature is worthy of worship).
15) You believe in one God or Supreme Energy. Superb! Follow Advaita philosophy
16) You want a Guru. Go ahead. Receive gyaan.(gyan yoga)
17) You don't want a Guru.. Help yourself ! Meditate, Study !(still gyana or raj yoga)
18) You believe in Female energy ! Shakti is worshipped.
19) You believe that every human being is equal. Yeah! You're awesome, come on let's celebrate Hinduism! 
 "Vasudhaiva kutumbakam" (the world is a family)
20) You don't have time to celebrate the festival.
Don't worry. One more festival is coming! There are multiple festivals every single day of the year.
21) You are a working person. Don't have time for religion. Its okay. You will still be a Hindu.
22) You like to go to temples. Devotion is loved.
23) You don't like to go to temples - no problem. You are still a Hindu!
24) You know that Hinduism ‚ò∫ is a way of life, with considerable freedom.
25) You believe that everything has God in it. So you worship your mother, father, guru, tree, River, Prani-matra, Earth, Universe!
26) And If you don't believe that everything has GOD in it - No problems. Respect your viewpoint.
27) "Sarve jana sukhino bhavantu " (May you all live happily)

You represent this! You're free to choose, my dear Hindu!

This is exactly the essence of Hinduism, all inclusive .. That is why it has withstood the test of time inspite of repeated onslaught both from within and outside, and assimilated every good aspects from everything . That is why it is eternal !!!

There is a saying in Rigveda, the first book ever known to mankind which depicts the Hinduism philosophy in a Nutshell - "Ano Bhadrah Krathavo Yanthu Vishwathah "- Let the knowledge come to us from every direction"

I haven't been to India since 1996. I was a woman alone, traveling with a backpack and Lonely Planet Guidebook, and the changes I've seen via videos such as yours are really amazing. One thing that strikes me since then is the growth of wealth in that country. It looks like some of it has trickled down and a more prosperous middle class is rising. What shocked me the most about India was all the homeless living on the streets, making cardboard shelters by rivers in the countryside and everywhere they weren't driven off. I didn't realize I was seeing a preview of what's now becoming a familiar sight in America -- homeless people everywhere. The economy has shifted again towards places with lots of excess people who will work in factories for pennies, relocating wealth once again. I'd go back if I could, but NOT alone and with a backpack at my age of 75.

Advices and request to all tourists who wish to visit Meghalaya you can go and do anything as you wish because money is yours, but make sure your safety must be in your hand by taking Local tour guide not Google Maps because as we had experienced the case of Raja raghuvanshi.

I just visited few days ago and it was kind of disappointing .. one , the travel roads are under widening process which apparently has been going on for last few years.. ( it must be difficult hence delayed in the hills ) .. so be prepared for not just green stretches but also super dusty mountain stretches with cut up hills and construction vehicles marring your view  I even noticed dynamite fuses to blow up the rocks obviously  .. Shillong is a cramped small place with traffic snarls everywhere but the people are good .. restaurants and markets close down by 8.30 pm, they took my last order at 8.30 and promptly served noodles soup ( I had asked for veg noodles which means chow mein everywhere else but they served boiled noodles in soup and said you wanted noodles so this is it  so please ask for fried chow mein if you don‚Äôt want the same fate ..any talk would be fruitless since it was closing time and I didn‚Äôt want to go hungry..everything is closed by 8.30- 9pm max and no shops open before 10-11 especially in rural areas ..be it food , pharmacy or whatever.. even tourist destinations don‚Äôt open before 8.30 mostly hence get up early to travel not to visit anything early morning..in short, people used to city life would find these challenges here ..also , there are mostly half to one n half km trek to reach many falls after you park your vehicle and then coming back so we get tired walking and can‚Äôt really cover a lot in one day .. not for people with joint problems or small children so better to enquire in advance !! What would be 5 mins walk for a local would be 15 for an outsider so consider that too !! Arwah cave had no lights when we visited around 3.30 -4 pm so had to view using mobile phone torch inside  natural views are beautiful but be prepared for tough walking bros .. also , there would be meat selling all around including beef and chicken which everyone won‚Äôt enjoy ( they could at least cover a bit for tourists maybe  .. decent restaurants I found in Shillong .. till 8.30 pm only.. I never entered a jadoh shop once I learned ja means rice and doh means any meat ..I really wished I would see picturesque scenes on the way but saw construction works and concrete homes mostly not the cute hilly cottages made with local materials that we see in pictures.. so not as good as I expected, though destinations are beautiful

The untapped potential in the northeast is immense, yet the government has not made significant strides in improving infrastructure, public transport, or road conditions. It's disheartening when I compare China's advancements with India's shortcomings, especially in infrastructure development. China has efficiently connected its mainland to regions like Tibet through high-speed bullet trains, a feat that remains elusive for us in 2024. The lack of such connectivity hampers the growth of the northeast, which holds the potential for a thriving tourist industry comparable to destinations like the Maldives. Unfortunately, our political landscape often hinders progress, and we tend to react only when faced with crises, rather than learning from successful models. Despite the challenges, I remain hopeful for positive changes in the future.

Beautiful video.
This is a place about which very few people in India know about, or take interest in.

To travel to a place where you know no one, where communication is mostly by sign language , and yet to feel at home there, says a lot about your enquiring nature.

Though the Khasi people are cut off from the rest of India, and have to live in very harsh climatic conditions, they, like you   have a very positive way of looking at life, always smiling,  friendly in their own way.

 Having very few visitors in this remote village makes them a little reserved, shy , wary and so they keep their distance from outsiders.

 But they are happy. The contentment on their faces is so obvious.

Perhaps tourism has not spoilt the peace  beauty and tranquility of this place , that it has a dream like quality, enhanced by the constant rain, heavy mist and rolling fog, which hides this enchanting  place from the rest of India.
Thank you for the effort you took to go to this  Shangri-la. and for sharing your memories of this abode of clouds.

Why India is Becoming a Nightmare for Tourists, While Pakistan Stands as a Better Alternative

In recent years, India‚Äôs reputation as a tourist destination has been rapidly declining. Once promoted as a land of culture and diversity, it is now being described by many international visitors as a nightmare ‚Äî even for Americans, Europeans, and other foreign travelers. The experiences shared by tourists paint a grim picture: constant harassment, unsafe environments, scams, and alarming crime rates.

Growing Safety Concerns in India

Tourists in India often face harassment from locals. Reports of theft in hotels, aggressive begging for food and money, and frequent scams are widely documented. Beyond these issues, the situation becomes even more alarming with the recurring incidents of sexual assault. Hundreds of reported cases, including horrifying gang rapes of female tourists, have made global headlines. Such incidents have raised serious questions about safety and respect for foreigners in the country.

A Negative Tourist Experience

Many travelers complain that India feels dirty, polluted, and filled with unpleasant smells. Instead of being able to enjoy the history or culture, tourists often find themselves battling discomfort, anxiety, and fear. Stories of cheap, unethical behavior ‚Äî from overcharging to tricking unsuspecting visitors ‚Äî are too common. For many foreign guests, the overall experience leaves them with regret rather than fond memories.

Pakistan: A Striking Contrast

In sharp contrast, Pakistan is gaining recognition as a safe, welcoming, and genuinely hospitable country. Tourists arriving in Pakistan often experience an opposite reality compared to India. Instead of harassment, they are met with kindness and generosity. Many visitors share stories of Pakistanis refusing to take money for food or services, offering free meals and even free accommodation.

Pakistani people are calm, loving, caring, down-to-earth, and deeply respectful towards guests. Safety concerns are minimal, and international travelers often remark on how secure they feel compared to other countries in the region.

Natural Beauty and Warm Hospitality

Pakistan is not just safe but also breathtakingly beautiful. From the majestic mountains of the north to the cultural richness of its cities, Pakistan offers everything a tourist could want without the fear and discomfort often reported in India. Another highlight that surprises visitors is the natural beauty of Pakistani people themselves, with many foreigners noting how strikingly attractive and graceful the locals are.

Conclusion

While India struggles with a growing reputation of being unsafe, dirty, and hostile for foreign visitors, Pakistan shines as a rising star in tourism. Its warm hospitality, safety, generosity, and unmatched beauty make it a far better destination for travelers seeking authentic and respectful cultural experiences. For many tourists, the choice is becoming clearer: India may be a nightmare, but Pakistan is a dream.

I also have a story I want to share

I had a bad experience in India during a long holiday two years ago. My father and I went there with our extended family for a vacation. When we arrived, everything went as usual. We visited many beautiful places and enjoyed our trip
After finishing the day‚Äôs activities, we returned to the villa. However, I, along with some of my cousins‚Äî2 boys and 4 girls‚Äîdecided to walk around an area near the villa that we hadn‚Äôt explored before
When we reached what looked like a small village, we came across a group of teenagers on motorcycles who were hanging out. Suddenly, one of them started catcalling my cousin. We ignored it and kept walking. Not long after, we heard shouting from behind us
When we turned around, we saw the same group of teenagers riding towards us. We stopped, curious about what they wanted. One of them spoke in English, asking where we stayed, saying that they wanted to "send us back after we finished exploring." I politely refused, not wanting to trouble them
But then, one of the boys suddenly got off his motorcycle and grabbed my female cousin‚Äôs hand, saying, ‚ÄúCome with us, it‚Äôll be fun.‚Äù My cousin told him to let go, but they kept insisting and trying to force her. I stepped in and told him firmly to release her
That only made things worse. They looked unhappy, spoke in a language I didn‚Äôt understand, and it seemed like they wanted to fight. There were about 4 to 5 of them. Several got off their bikes and looked ready to attack us, especially the boys in our group
Luckily, my cousins and I had some martial arts training. One of my cousins, who was 20 at the time, was especially skilled‚Äîhe had won three gold medals in silat competitions since his father was a silat master. A fight broke out on the street
At one point, my cousin managed to punch one of them in the solar plexus, leaving him almost fainting and struggling to breathe. Thankfully, no weapons were involved, just barehanded fighting. In the end, we all came out okay, though some of us had minor injuries and bruises
By the time Maghrib (dusk) approached, we decided to head back to the villa. When we arrived, our family noticed something was wrong‚Äîour clothes were dirty, and my face was swollen near the eye. We explained what had happened. They were worried, but also relieved that we knew how to defend ourselves.
After that, the rest of the week went smoothly, and we enjoyed our stay at the villa. Only the first day was tense because of that incident


Note: 

‚ÄúSorry if my writing isn‚Äôt very formal, but I just wanted to share my experience. This story is not meant to put down any country, it‚Äôs simply for sharing.‚Äù

I‚Äôm honestly fed up seeing vloggers do this. If you decide to travel solo, surely a slum isn‚Äôt the first place you‚Äôd decide to go. It feels like this was done for attention, if she genuinely wanted to explore the ‚Äòcultural roots of India', a quick Google search would have given her the basics. Travel etiquette 101: you don‚Äôt just wander alone through unfamiliar streets in a place you‚Äôve never been and then act shocked when things dont go the way you expected them to, miss gurl basic survival skills matter more than just walking around.
And to add onto what the comments have been saying, imagine thinking a country of 1.4 billion people is ‚Äònot worth traveling to‚Äô just because someone only filmed the corners that made them uncomfortable. India isn‚Äôt a theme park curated for foreigners, it‚Äôs a living, breathing country.
I recently moved to India permanently, and even before that I visited frequently and while I‚Äôve seen similar situations happen to others, its never happened to me. Poverty exists everywhere, literally even South Korea has its fair share of issues(the hongdae men making women feel unsafe and the ongoing 4B movement says enough) but that doesn‚Äôt stop tourists does it?
Yes, India has challenges, but it‚Äôs also home to 1.4 billion people, to reduce those lives to slums and stares isn‚Äôt just recording you experiences it‚Äôs curating a stereotype. If someone filmed only the worst alleys in your city, would you call that an honest story? Perspective matters.

As an Indian, it breaks my heart to see these comments. Yes, I don't deny that aspects of India are bad. Yes, it is dangerous to travel to it, especially as a sole female traveller. But does that justify comments like 'india is terrible,' 'why would anyone travel to india,' and such?? 

first of all, before travelling ANYWHERE, do your research. Is it really the most prudent choice, as a foreign woman, to travel to India by yourself? Not just that, you literally went to ONE part of India and now making claims like 'I hate India?' 

Hate towards India and Indians has become so normalised in our society. How would we respond if a person posted 'I hate Nigeria,' 'I hate Mexico,' 'I hate Brazil?' Wouldn't we all be mad? Yet when it comes to India, it is perfectly alright to hate.

It is not against this Korean Youtuber. I'm truly sorry you had a bad time here. I acknowledge that India is dangerous and has poor aspects. But you cannot, from a first world country, go to a third world one and expect it to be amazing. You cannot post media that expresses hatred for an entire nation based on your experience. And to see all these comments, some from foreigners and, most heartbreakingly from many Indians themselves, hating on this country, it really fills me with sorrow.

It‚Äôs unacceptable to create any kind of disturbance, especially toward a foreign guest, and doubly so if she is a woman. In India, we say ‚ÄòAtithi Devo Bhava‚Äô‚Äîthe guest is god‚Äîand we honor guests accordingly. Though I‚Äôm Hindu, I‚Äôm not Indian by nationality. I lived in Chennai for many years as a student, and I deeply respect you as a foreign woman.

I recognize that in countries like the USA or EU, most places seem safe, but when traveling to a place with different cultures and languages, the risks can increase. It‚Äôs always prudent not to visit alone in unfamiliar areas, especially if local norms or preferences might lead to misunderstandings.

From what I saw, your video was filmed by someone else, with clips of hugging or being chased‚Äîsuggesting you didn‚Äôt go alone or had no consent to include those scenes. It feels like the video was created intentionally to highlight India‚Äôs drawbacks without showing the kindness and safety that many people here offer.

I am also Asian and who went on a solo trip to India. Be prepared to be full on bombarded by stares, attention and no respect of personal space. (They will breathe down your neck)
Better to just ignore advances, avoid messy areas and stay in the hotel if you feel unsafe. Try not to eat street food that is prepared in unsanitary conditions, avoid having any water (including ice)
Dont make eye contact and try not to go out too late at night. 

Overall, I think, just have to make sure that you have good awareness. Some people are just curios about you but some people have bad intentions. But that happens everywhere in the world.

I dont understand why do tourists intentionally travel in slum areas in India and then complaint about being harassed or scammed. People who live in slum areas are mostly uneducated, poor and desperate for money people. What do you expect from them. Stop doing that people. Instead go to more safe places like 5 star hotels and reputed restaurants with more classy people. Slums are slums regardless of which country you are travelling to. I am not against poor people but if your travelling to place where people dont have money or basic necessities they can sometimes behave in weird ways. Dont believe me try living in cities like Philadelphia in usa or Vancouver in canada with so much crime and drugs problems. If you are a foreigner my advice to you guys is to stay 5 star hotels and ask hotels to provide you cabs and tourist guides. So you can travel safely. No country is super safe nowadays. The only way you can keep yourself safe is by making right decisions well in advance. I have seen these kind of behaviours in many videos from some of the most developed countries. But they are also about the poor slum areas of any cities or areas with more drug problems. If you will only go to country to show slums, snakes and scammers in a country thats what you will face. I have visited India twice. I went to Delhi and never felt in danger but I was also with two other people. You should definitely travel in a group. Do not go outside at night by yourself. The begging children are very annoying. I ignored them as much as possible. Do not drink the water (bottled water only) and do not eat the street food. You will get sick if you are from Europe or the states. Be careful of what you eat. If you have white skin - you will be noticed and bothered. Many Indians wanted their photo taken with me, especially when I went to Bhopal. They do not get many pale people visiting there. Be careful traveling there especially if you are a woman, Do not walk around alone. Dress modesty as much as possible. I covered my hair and I wore long skirts with stretch pants on underneath. The temples are beautiful but the slums are depressing and dangerous. Make sure you buy travelers insurance that will cover any medical costs, incase you get hurt while in India. It is very dirty. Trash everywhere and there is a rat problem. Make sure you get vaccines to protect you from diseases. Rabies is a problem there. Malaria is a problem. I had to get six vaccines before going there. Be prepared.

I solo backpacked in 2000 at age 21 from New Delhi to Kolkata for a few months.  I‚Äôve been to 90 countries since, but that trip was the hardest I‚Äôve ever been on.  I was living in Japan at the time, which I thought was a culture shock but India was a culture shock on steroids.  I grew up in London in a diverse area near the predominantly Indian neighborhoods, best Indian food is in London.  I was a journalist so I didn‚Äôt have ‚Äúas much‚Äù torment as the woman in this video (having a real press pass helped tremendously to get the harassers to back off).  Overall, I vowed I would never go back 

But then I did‚Ä¶. six months later I went to Mumbai and Goa, and it was night and day.  I stayed with a documentary filmmaker and his family in Mumbai for a month, and rented a motorcycle to ride around Goa.  I loved it the second time.  Hated it the first time.  Also back then all I had was a paper travel book.  No apps.  No internet.  The second time I traveled on my British passport, which made a big difference also than the first time when I traveled on my American passport.  

I‚Äôve given a lot of places a second chance.

Oh, please ‚Äî let‚Äôs be clear here. How can you generalize an entire country based on one individual‚Äôs negative experience in a particular region? Criticizing India as a whole based on limited exposure is not just unfair ‚Äî it's factually misleading.

Yes, India faces developmental challenges, like many nations, but calling it underdeveloped ignores its rapid economic growth, technological advancements, and cultural richness. And comparing it to China, while brushing over China's own deeply rooted issues like censorship, human rights concerns, and significant poverty in rural regions, is equally unbalanced.

Every country has its strengths and flaws. The real issue here is lack of research. If someone genuinely wanted to explore Indian culture, there are countless destinations ‚Äî historically rich cities, serene spiritual retreats, world-class heritage sites, and modern urban centers ‚Äî far beyond the "outskirts" that were described.

As someone who has lived in India, I can confidently say many destinations here are underrated gems, places that feel like heaven and offer unforgettable experiences.

If China is portrayed as a "godly" superpower, then why do major social issues, income gaps, and unaddressed rural poverty still exist there? A superpower should set an example ‚Äî not just economically, but also socially . 
I am not like you dragging the whole country in middle but just a remainder for you to take account of not the only flaws that were portrayed 


In short: sweeping generalizations serve no one. Travel experiences should be based on open-minded exploration and proper research ‚Äî not on assumptions and selective storytelling.

Dear Travellers,

As a South Indian, I genuinely feel sorry for what this traveler had to go through. Sadly, many parts of North India ‚Äî especially crowded cities like Delhi ‚Äî can be overwhelming, even for Indians ourselves. But to any foreign tourist watching this: India is vast and diverse. Please don‚Äôt judge the entire country based on one region. If you're planning to explore India, I strongly recommend starting with South India.

South India offers a beautiful blend of safety, hospitality, culture, and natural beauty. Whether it's the backwaters of Kerala, the clean and tech-savvy city of Bengaluru, the heritage of Tamil Nadu, or the beaches of Goa ‚Äî you'll find peace, kindness, and a slower pace of life.

Women, including solo female travelers, often report feeling safer and more respected in the South. Public transport is more orderly, people are warm, and the food is just incredible.
This shouldn't have happened to her ‚Äî especially in the capital city. We must do better as a country to protect our guests. 

Until then, I urge travellers: choose South India for a safer, soulful, and unforgettable experience.

This is a true story my father told me.  My father who was born and raised in India left when he was 13.  However, he would make yearly trips to his home village in India.  Yearly.  My father is a good 220lb guy who was a correctional officer.  So he has dealt with hardened criminals and mobs bosses all his life.  On his one trip he was about to come back and booked a taxi from his village to the Amritsar airport.  The taxi driver, instead of taking him to the airport, stopped at the outskirts of the city limits and demanded his money.  My father refused, and after some argument my father gave him some money.  Along came a husky bhappa sikh who kept offering my father for help, to come to his place to rest and stay the night.  My father felt the whole situation was off, said no, and got on a rickshaw to go to his niece who had a home in Amritsar.  It was more than an hour away on rickshaw.  But during that whole time the husky sikh followed him from a distance.   They could not find the house, since India has no street signs.  My father then told the rickshaw guy to take him to a nearest police station.  That is how he escaped that scary situation.  India is dangerous not just for women but also for foreign men.  After sun down, India is whole different ball game.  Avoid India at all cost if you can.

Travel: Use premium app-based cabs like Uber Black for safer and more comfortable travel.
Destinations: Consider exploring tourist-friendly zones in major cities like:
few of the good Starting Points:
    Delhi: Areas like South Delhi (e.g., Hauz Khas, Khan Market)

    Hyderabad: Neighborhoods like Banjara Hills or Jubilee Hills.

I have traveled all over India on my own and lived in India. It is difficult. A daily struggle. The situations shown here in the video are real. I have experienced them regularly. You learn to recognize the situations better over time and can avoid some of them. It improved a bit when I was able to speak a little Hindi. But it remains a very difficult country for women to travel.
But there are so many beautiful memories and unexpectedly friendly people who helped and welcomed me. India is a love-hate relationship. I hate it for all those shown in this video. But I love this country for the unexpectedly great moments, special people and a certain magic. This video focuses on the negative. Its a shame that she didnt have the opportunity to experience the truly beautiful moments and encounters that this country can offer.

Bruv, I went to India in 2017 with another friend (both guys) and the moment we stepped out of Delhi airport, the uber driver just didn't want to show up. Naturally, the scammers came. At that point I didn't read up or was as well versed against scams. So they promised us a fee that was much lower than the uber and agreed to take us to our hotel. What we failed to realize at that point was that another guy joined his driver friend with us in the frontseat. We didn't think much of it back then but it was his accomplice. Halfway during the ride, my friend kept noticing the driver going around in circles, citing "road blocks due to festivals/holidays", something felt off already. But I still was naive back then so I didn't really look at the route he was going in. 

After a while, he kept doing the same thing and said that he'd "inform" our hotel we were gonna be late and weirdly asked for my hotel reservation papers (which I stupidly gave) - and it was obviously a lie because he tried to cancel our hotel bookings. At this point we already knew it was a scam but we wanted to play along and see how it'd turn out. We got a bit frustrated and told him to stop us somewhere near our hotel. Lo and behold: he stopped us right outside a TRAVEL AGENCY. LOL! We were like wtf, but were ushered in anyway. Of course we said no, because the mf inside told us our hotel has cancelled our rooms due to "some issue" (driver was supposedly talking to the hotel staff during the car ride trying to cancel our rooms). The prices were also way more expensive, and we just firmly stormed out of there, paid the low cab fee and walked off. They looked pissed and bewildered but I was ready to let 15 years of Muay Thai go if I had to. I then googled the way and we walked all the way to our hotel for around 10mins, through some underbridge slums and insane traffic filled with thick smog.

As you would expect, the hotel had no issue checking us in! Afterwards everything in the trip went great. The service at the hotel was very good, butter curry was insanely delicious that we ate there 2-3 times. As for the rest of the trip, it was nothing short of amazing. Simply because - all the other trips I booked was through agoda/trip advisor, things like Delhi by Cycle (rode bicycles through old neighbourhoods, slums, new and old delhi, monuments etc - a very organized guided tour with great tour guides checking up on our safety, recc'ing us great restaurants to go to). Every place I booked (Taj Mahal, Red Fort etc) had a tour guide and a private van, warned us of the local scams etc. But obviously if you don't want to buy jewellery from their "friend's" shop, don't. They won't force you. Same shit happened when kids would walk up to us, I'd just give the fk face and walk away "arrogantly" so they know not to bother you. If anything, just stare. I understand this may be "rude" but you certainly do not want 20 kids chasing you for $ when you've given one. It opens the floodgates as you can see in this video.


Ever since then, I've read up on almost all the scams before travelling to said destination and watched tons of videos on the topic. Think Honest Guide/Karl Rock, Scambaiter/Jim Browning/Scammer Payback, and those Europe Metro theft ones. I also do not carry any LOUSY bags that AREN'T anti-theft while travelling. Why I say this is because I use PACSAFE and sling my shit to the front, wallet/cash is all locked up in the anti-theft zipper mechanisms, and phone has to be zipped up in my pocket OR zipped up and hooked in my slingbag. I suspect this will only matter if you travel to Spain/Barcelona/France or yea India lol, where there are many snatch thieves. I am constantly on guard and I'm observing my surroundings no matter where I go.
